统计场论第十章

Directed paths in random media

10.1 Introduction

Many physical problems involve calculating sums over paths. Each path could represent one possible physical realization of an object such as a polymer, in which case the weight of the path is the probability of that configuration. The weights themselves could be imaginary as in the case of Feynman paths describing the amplitude for the propagation of a particle. Path integral calculations are now a standard tool of the theoretical physicist, with many excellent books devoted to the subject [R.P. Feynman and A.R. Hibbs, Quantum Mechanics and Path Integrals (McGraw-Hill, New York, 1965)]; [F.W. Wiegel, Introduction to Path-Integral Methods in Physics and Polymer Science (World Scientific, Singapore, 1986)].

What happens to sums over paths in the presence of quenched disorder in the medium? Individual paths are no longer weighted simply by their length, but are influenced by the impurities along their route. The sum may be dominated by "optimal" paths pinned to the impurities; the optimal paths usually forming complex hierarchical structures. Physical examples are provided by the interface of the random bond Ising model in two dimensions, and by magnetic flux lines in superconductors. The actual value of the sum naturally depends on the particular realization of randomness and varies from sample to sample. I shall initially motivate the problem in the context of the high-temperature expansion for the random bond Ising model. Introducing the sums over paths for such a lattice model avoids the difficulties associated with short distance cutoffs. Furthermore, the Ising model is sufficiently well understood to make the nature of various approximations more evident.

The high-temperature correlation functions of the Ising model are dominated by the shortest paths connecting the spins. Such configurations that exclude loops and overhangs, are referred to as directed paths. They dominate the asymptotic behavior of the sum over distances that are much longer than the correlation length. Most of this chapter is devoted to describing the statistical properties of sums over such directed paths. As in all multiplicative noise processes, the probability distribution for the sum is broad. Hence Monte Carlo simulations may not be an appropriate tool for numerical studies, failing to find typical members of the ensemble. Instead, we shall focus on a transfer matrix method that allows a numerical evaluation of the sum in polynomial time in the length of the path. The results indeed show that the sum has a broad probability distribution that resembles (but is not quite) log-normal.

To obtain analytical information about this probability distribution we shall introduce the replica method for examining the moments. It can be shown easily that the one-dimensional sum has a log-normal distribution. The moments of the sum over directed paths in two dimensions can be obtained by using a simple Bethe Ansatz. The implications and limitations of this approach are discussed. There is little analytical information in three and higher dimensions, but a variety of numerical results are available, mostly by taking advantage of a mapping to the growing surfaces introduced in the previous chapter.

The spin glass problem describes a mixture of ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic bonds. The resulting sums in the high-temperature expansion involve products over a random mixture of positive and negative factors. The calculation of moments is somewhat different from the case of purely positive random bonds. However, we shall demonstrate that the scaling behavior of the distribution is unchanged. A similar sum involving products of random signs is encountered in calculating the probability of an electron tunneling under a random potential. In the strongly localized limit, it is again sufficient to focus on the interference of the forward scattering (directed) paths. A magnetic field introduces random phases in the sum; while to describe the tunneling of an electron in the presence of spin-orbit scattering requires examining the evolution of a two component spinor and keeping track of products of random matrices. We shall argue that all these cases are in fact described by the same universal probability distribution which, however, does retain some remnant of the underlying symmetries of the original electronic Hamiltonian.

Yet another class of directed paths is encountered in the context of light scattering in turbulent media. Assuming that inelastic scattering can be neglected, the intensity of the beam is left unchanged, and the evolution is unitary. Due to the constraint of unitarity the resulting directed paths are described by a probability distribution belonging to a new universality class. We shall introduce a discrete matrix model that explicitly takes care of the unitarity constraint. In this model, several properties of the resulting sum over paths can be calculated exactly.

10.2 High-T expansions for the random-bond Ising model

Consider a ddd-dimensional hypercubic lattice of NNN sites. On each site there is an Ising variable σi=±1\sigma_{i}= \pm 1σi​=±1, and the spins interact through a Hamiltonian

H=−∑⟨ij⟩Jijσiσj.\begin{equation*} \mathcal{H}=-\sum_{\langle i j\rangle} J_{i j} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j} . \tag{10.1} \end{equation*}H=−⟨ij⟩∑​Jij​σi​σj​.​(10.1)​

The symbol ⟨ij⟩\langle i j\rangle⟨ij⟩ implies that the sum is restricted to the dNd NdN nearest-neighbor bonds on the lattice. The bonds {Jij}\left\{J_{i j}\right\}{Jij​} are quenched random variables, independently chosen from a probability distribution p(J)p(J)p(J). For each realization of random bonds, the partition function is computed as

Z[Jij]=∑{σi}exp⁡(−βH)=∑{σi}⟨ij⟩eKijσiσj,\begin{equation*} Z\left[J_{i j}\right]=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}} \exp (-\beta \mathcal{H})=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}\langle i j\rangle} \mathrm{e}^{K_{i j} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}}, \tag{10.2} \end{equation*}Z[Jij​]={σi​}∑​exp(−βH)={σi​}⟨ij⟩∑​eKij​σi​σj​,​(10.2)​

where the sums are over the 2N2^{N}2N possible configurations of spins, β=1/(kBT)\beta=1 /\left(k_{\mathrm{B}} T\right)β=1/(kB​T) and Kij=βJijK_{i j}=\beta J_{i j}Kij​=βJij​. To obtain a high-temperature expansion, it is more convenient to organize the partition function in powers of tanh⁡Kij\tanh K_{i j}tanhKij​. Since (σiσj)2=1\left(\sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}\right)^{2}=1(σi​σj​)2=1, the Boltzmann factor for each bond can be written as

eKijσiσj=eKij+e−Kij2+eKij−e−Kij2σiσj=cosh⁡Kij(1+τijσiσj),\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{K_{i j} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}}=\frac{\mathrm{e}^{K_{i j}}+\mathrm{e}^{-K_{i j}}}{2}+\frac{\mathrm{e}^{K_{i j}}-\mathrm{e}^{-K_{i j}}}{2} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}=\cosh K_{i j}\left(1+\tau_{i j} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}\right), \tag{10.3} \end{equation*}eKij​σi​σj​=2eKij​+e−Kij​​+2eKij​−e−Kij​​σi​σj​=coshKij​(1+τij​σi​σj​),​(10.3)​

where τij≡tanh⁡Kij\tau_{i j} \equiv \tanh K_{i j}τij​≡tanhKij​. Applying this transformation to each bond of the lattice results in

Z[Jij]=∑{σi}e∑⟨ij⟩Kijσiσj=Cˉ∑{σi}⟨ij⟩(1+τijσiσj),\begin{equation*} Z\left[J_{i j}\right]=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}} \mathrm{e}^{\sum_{\langle i j\rangle} K_{i j} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}}=\bar{C} \sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}\langle i j\rangle}\left(1+\tau_{i j} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}\right), \tag{10.4} \end{equation*}Z[Jij​]={σi​}∑​e∑⟨ij⟩​Kij​σi​σj​=Cˉ{σi​}⟨ij⟩∑​(1+τij​σi​σj​),​(10.4)​

and

Cˉ≡(∏⟨ij⟩cosh⁡Kij).\bar{C} \equiv\left(\prod_{\langle i j\rangle} \cosh K_{i j}\right) .Cˉ≡​⟨ij⟩∏​coshKij​​.

The term Cˉ\bar{C}Cˉ is non-singular, and will be mostly ignored henceforth. The final product in Eq. (10.4) generates 2dN2^{d N}2dN terms which can be represented diagrammatically by drawing lines connecting sites iii and jjj for each factor of τijσiσj\tau_{i j} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}τij​σi​σj​. Each site now obtains a factor of σipi\sigma_{i}^{p_{i}}σipi​​, where 0≤pi≤2d0 \leq p_{i} \leq 2 d0≤pi​≤2d is the number of bonds emanating from iii. Summing over the two possible values σi=±1\sigma_{i}= \pm 1σi​=±1 gives a factor of 2 if pip_{i}pi​ is even and 0 if pip_{i}pi​ is odd. Thus the only graphs that survive the sum have an even number of lines passing through each site. The contribution of each graph G\mathcal{G}G is the product of τij\tau_{i j}τij​ for the bonds making up the graph, resulting in

Z[Jij]=2N×Cˉ∑G(∏⟨ij⟩∈Gτij).\begin{equation*} Z\left[J_{i j}\right]=2^{N} \times \bar{C} \sum_{\mathcal{G}}\left(\prod_{\langle i j\rangle \in \mathcal{G}} \tau_{i j}\right) . \tag{10.5} \end{equation*}Z[Jij​]=2N×CˉG∑​​⟨ij⟩∈G∏​τij​​.​(10.5)​

For a ddd-dimensional hypercubic lattice the smallest closed graph is a square of four bonds and the next graph has six bonds. Thus,

Z[Jij]=2N×Cˉ[1+∑PτP1τP2τP3τP4+O(τ6)+⋯ ]\begin{equation*} Z\left[J_{i j}\right]=2^{N} \times \bar{C}\left[1+\sum_{P} \tau_{P 1} \tau_{P 2} \tau_{P 3} \tau_{P 4}+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{6}\right)+\cdots\right] \tag{10.6} \end{equation*}Z[Jij​]=2N×Cˉ[1+P∑​τP1​τP2​τP3​τP4​+O(τ6)+⋯]​(10.6)​

where the sum runs over the Nd(d−1)/2N d(d-1) / 2Nd(d−1)/2 plaquettes on the lattice and τPα\tau_{P \alpha}τPα​ indicates one of the four bonds around plaquette PPP. A quench averaged free energy is now obtained as

ln⁡Z‾N=ln⁡2+dln⁡cosh⁡K‾‾+d(d−1)2τˉ4+⋯ ,\begin{equation*} \frac{\overline{\ln Z}}{N}=\ln 2+d \overline{\overline{\ln \cosh K}}+\frac{d(d-1)}{2} \bar{\tau}^{4}+\cdots, \tag{10.7} \end{equation*}NlnZ​=ln2+dlncoshK+2d(d−1)​τˉ4+⋯,​(10.7)​

where the over-lines indicate averages over the probability distribution p(J)p(J)p(J). The expansion up to this order is quite similar to that of the non-random Ising model in Sec. 7.2, with τˉ\bar{\tau}τˉ in place of the pure τ\tauτ. However, starting with order of τ8\tau^{8}τ8 we need to evaluate averages of τij2\tau_{i j}^{2}τij2​ (and higher moments) quickly removing any semblance to the expansion of the pure Ising model.

The same conclusion applies to expansions for other spin operators. For example the two-spin correlation function is given by

⟨σmσn⟩=∑{σi}e∑⟨ijKijσiσjZσmσn=CˉZ∑{σi}σmσn∏⟨ij⟩(1+τijσiσj)\begin{equation*} \left\langle\sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}\right\rangle=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}} \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\sum_{\langle i j} K_{i j} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}}}{Z} \sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}=\frac{\bar{C}}{Z} \sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}} \sigma_{m} \sigma_{n} \prod_{\langle i j\rangle}\left(1+\tau_{i j} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{j}\right) \tag{10.8} \end{equation*}⟨σm​σn​⟩={σi​}∑​Ze∑⟨ij​Kij​σi​σj​​σm​σn​=ZCˉ​{σi​}∑​σm​σn​⟨ij⟩∏​(1+τij​σi​σj​)​(10.8)​

The terms in the numerator involve an additional factor of σmσn\sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}σm​σn​. To get a finite value after summing over σm=±1\sigma_{m}= \pm 1σm​=±1 and σn=±1\sigma_{n}= \pm 1σn​=±1 we have to examine graphs with an odd number of bonds emanating from these external sites. After canceling the common factors between the numerator and denominator, we obtain

⟨σmσn⟩=∑Gmn(Π⟨ij⟩∈Gmnτij)∑G(Π⟨ij⟩∈Gτij)\begin{equation*} \left\langle\sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}\right\rangle=\frac{\sum_{\mathcal{G}_{m n}}\left(\Pi_{\langle i j\rangle \in \mathcal{G}_{m n}} \tau_{i j}\right)}{\sum_{\mathcal{G}}\left(\Pi_{\langle i j\rangle \in \mathcal{G}} \tau_{i j}\right)} \tag{10.9} \end{equation*}⟨σm​σn​⟩=∑G​(Π⟨ij⟩∈G​τij​)∑Gmn​​(Π⟨ij⟩∈Gmn​​τij​)​​(10.9)​

Whereas the graphs in G\mathcal{G}G have an even number of bonds going through each site, those of Gmn\mathcal{G}_{m n}Gmn​ have an odd number of bonds going through the external points mmm and nnn. In calculating the quench averaged correlation function, the simplest graphs involving single occurrences of each bond give contributions similar to the corresponding terms for the pure model with τ\tauτ replaced by τˉ\bar{\tau}τˉ. However, the graphs with multiple factors of a particular τij\tau_{i j}τij​ involve higher moments and complicate the computation.

As Eqs. (10.6) and (10.8) indicate, the partition function and correlation functions of the random system are themselves random quantities, dependent on all the bonds JijJ_{i j}Jij​. It may not be sufficient to just characterize the mean value of ZZZ (or ln⁡Z\ln ZlnZ ), since the full information about these fluctuating quantities is only contained in their respective probability distributions p(Z)p(Z)p(Z) and p(⟨σmσn⟩)p\left(\left\langle\sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}\right\rangle\right)p(⟨σm​σn​⟩).

A particularly useful way of describing a random variable is through its characteristic function, which is simply the Fourier transform of its probability distribution function (PDF), i.e.

p~(k)=⟨e−ikx⟩=∫dxp(x)e−ikx\begin{equation*} \widetilde{p}(k)=\left\langle\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} k x}\right\rangle=\int \mathrm{d} x p(x) \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} k x} \tag{10.10} \end{equation*}p​(k)=⟨e−ikx⟩=∫dxp(x)e−ikx​(10.10)​

Moments of the distribution can be obtained by expanding p~(k)\widetilde{p}(k)p​(k) in powers of kkk,

p~(k)=⟨∑n=0∞(−ik)nn!xn⟩=∑n=0∞(−ik)nn!⟨xn⟩.\begin{equation*} \widetilde{p}(k)=\left\langle\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(-\mathrm{i} k)^{n}}{n!} x^{n}\right\rangle=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(-\mathrm{i} k)^{n}}{n!}\left\langle x^{n}\right\rangle . \tag{10.11} \end{equation*}p​(k)=⟨n=0∑∞​n!(−ik)n​xn⟩=n=0∑∞​n!(−ik)n​⟨xn⟩.​(10.11)​

Similarly, cumulants of the random variable are generated by the expansion of the logarithm of the characteristic function as

ln⁡p~(k)=∑n=1∞(−ik)nn!⟨xn⟩c.\begin{equation*} \ln \widetilde{p}(k)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-\mathrm{i} k)^{n}}{n!}\left\langle x^{n}\right\rangle_{c} . \tag{10.12} \end{equation*}lnp​(k)=n=1∑∞​n!(−ik)n​⟨xn⟩c​.​(10.12)​

10.3 The one-dimensional chain

The calculations of Section 7.3 are easily generalized to the case of the random bond Ising model in d=1d=1d=1 (and zero field). In particular, for the open chain of NNN sites, we have

Z=2N∏α=1N−1cosh⁡Kα\begin{equation*} Z=2^{N} \prod_{\alpha=1}^{N-1} \cosh K_{\alpha} \tag{10.13} \end{equation*}Z=2Nα=1∏N−1​coshKα​​(10.13)​

where Kα≡Kαα+1K_{\alpha} \equiv K_{\alpha \alpha+1}Kα​≡Kαα+1​ is the interaction between neighboring sites. There is also only one graph that contributes to the two-point correlation function,

⟨σmσn⟩=∑{σi}e∑iKiσiσi+1Zσmσn=∏α=mn−1τα.\begin{equation*} \left\langle\sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}\right\rangle=\sum_{\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}} \frac{\mathrm{e}^{\sum_{i} K_{i} \sigma_{i} \sigma_{i+1}}}{Z} \sigma_{m} \sigma_{n}=\prod_{\alpha=m}^{n-1} \tau_{\alpha} . \tag{10.14} \end{equation*}⟨σm​σn​⟩={σi​}∑​Ze∑i​Ki​σi​σi+1​​σm​σn​=α=m∏n−1​τα​.​(10.14)​

Since the partition function is the sum of N−1N-1N−1 independent variables,

ln⁡ZN=ln⁡2+∑α=1N−1ln⁡cosh⁡KαN,\begin{equation*} \frac{\ln Z}{N}=\ln 2+\sum_{\alpha=1}^{N-1} \frac{\ln \cosh K_{\alpha}}{N}, \tag{10.15} \end{equation*}NlnZ​=ln2+α=1∑N−1​NlncoshKα​​,​(10.15)​

we can use the central limit theorem to conclude that as N→∞N \rightarrow \inftyN→∞ the probability distribution p(ln⁡Z/N)p(\ln Z / N)p(lnZ/N) has a Gaussian distribution with mean

ln⁡Z‾=N(ln⁡2+ln⁡cosh⁡K‾),\begin{equation*} \overline{\ln Z}=N(\ln 2+\overline{\ln \cosh K}), \tag{10.16} \end{equation*}lnZ=N(ln2+lncoshK),​(10.16)​

and variance

(ln⁡Z)c2‾≡(ln⁡Z)2‾−(ln⁡Z)2‾=N(ln⁡cosh⁡K)c2‾\begin{equation*} \overline{(\ln Z)_{c}^{2}} \equiv \overline{(\ln Z)^{2}}-\overline{(\ln Z)^{2}}=N \overline{(\ln \cosh K)_{c}^{2}} \tag{10.17} \end{equation*}(lnZ)c2​​≡(lnZ)2​−(lnZ)2​=N(lncoshK)c2​​​(10.17)​

(We have ignored the small difference between NNN and N−1N-1N−1 in the thermodynamic limit.) Similarly, for the correlation function of two points separated by a distance ttt, we have

ln⁡⟨σ0σt⟩=∑α=0t−1ln⁡τα\begin{equation*} \ln \left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle=\sum_{\alpha=0}^{t-1} \ln \tau_{\alpha} \tag{10.18} \end{equation*}ln⟨σ0​σt​⟩=α=0∑t−1​lnτα​​(10.18)​

As long as the random variables on the bonds are independently distributed, the cumulants of ln⁡⟨σ0σt⟩\ln \left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangleln⟨σ0​σt​⟩ are given by,

{ln⁡⟨σ0σt⟩‾‾=tln⁡tanh⁡K‾(ln⁡⟨σ0σt⟩)c2‾=t(ln⁡tanh⁡K)c2‾⋮⋮(ln⁡⟨σ0σt⟩)cp‾=t(ln⁡tanh⁡K)cp‾.(10.19)\left\{\begin{array}{c} \overline{\overline{\ln \left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle}}=t \overline{\ln \tanh K} \tag{10.19}\\ \overline{\left(\ln \left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle\right)_{c}^{2}}=t \overline{(\ln \tanh K)_{c}^{2}} \\ \vdots \\ \vdots \\ \overline{\left(\ln \left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle\right)_{c}^{p}}=t \overline{(\ln \tanh K)_{c}^{p}} . \end{array}\right.⎩⎨⎧​ln⟨σ0​σt​⟩​​=tlntanhK(ln⟨σ0​σt​⟩)c2​​=t(lntanhK)c2​​⋮⋮(ln⟨σ0​σt​⟩)cp​​=t(lntanhK)cp​​.​(10.19)

In the following sections we shall try to obtain similar information about probability distribution functions for the partition and correlation functions in higher dimensions. To do so, we shall employ the replica method for calculating the moments of the distribution. For example, the cumulants of the free energy are given by

Zn‾=enln⁡Z‾=exp⁡[nln⁡Z‾+n22(ln⁡Z)c2‾+⋯+npp!(ln⁡Z)cp‾+⋯ ],\begin{equation*} \overline{Z^{n}}=\overline{\mathrm{e}^{n \ln Z}}=\exp \left[n \overline{\ln Z}+\frac{n^{2}}{2} \overline{(\ln Z)_{c}^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{n^{p}}{p!} \overline{(\ln Z)_{c}^{p}}+\cdots\right], \tag{10.20} \end{equation*}Zn=enlnZ=exp[nlnZ+2n2​(lnZ)c2​​+⋯+p!np​(lnZ)cp​​+⋯],​(10.20)​

where we have taken advantage of Eq. (10.12), replacing ( −ik-\mathrm{i} k−ik ) with nnn. Usually, the moments on the left-hand side of the above equation are known only for integer nnn, while the evaluation of the cumulants on the right-hand side relies on an expansion around n=0n=0n=0. This is one of the difficulties associated with the problem of deducing a probability distribution p(x)p(x)p(x), from the knowledge of its moments xn‾\overline{x^{n}}xn. There is in fact a rigorous theorem that the probability distribution cannot be uniquely inferred if its nnnth moment increases faster than n!n!n! [N.I. Akhiezer, The Classical Moment Problem (Oliver and Boyd, London, 1965)]. Most of the distributions of interest to us (such as the above lognormal) do not satisfy this condition! Similar problems are encountered in the replica studies of spin glasses [M. Mézard, G. Parisi, and M.A. Virasoro, Spin Glass Theory and Beyond (World Scientific, Singapore, 1987)]. It turns out that many of the difficulties associated with a rigorous inversion are related to the behavior at the tail (extreme values) of the distribution. Most of the information of interest to us is contained in the "bulk" of the distribution which is easier to investigate. Rather than taking a rigorous approach to the problem, we shall illustrate the difficulties and their resolution by examining the above one dimensional example in some detail, since it actually presents a worst case scenario for deducing a distribution from its moments.

We used the central limit theorem to deduce that the probability distribution for ⟨σ0σt⟩\left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle⟨σ0​σt​⟩ is log-normal. Its moments are computed from,

⟨σ0σt⟩n‾=∏α=0t−1ταn‾=(enln⁡τ‾)t=exp⁡[t∑pnpp!‾ln⁡τ)cp‾].\begin{equation*} \overline{\left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle^{n}}=\prod_{\alpha=0}^{t-1} \overline{\tau_{\alpha}^{n}}=\left(\overline{\mathrm{e}^{n \ln \tau}}\right)^{t}=\exp \left[t \sum_{p} \frac{n^{p}}{\overline{p!}} \overline{\ln \tau)_{c}^{p}}\right] . \tag{10.21} \end{equation*}⟨σ0​σt​⟩n​=α=0∏t−1​ταn​​=(enlnτ)t=exp[tp∑​p!​np​lnτ)cp​​].​(10.21)​

Let us consider a binary distribution in which τ\tauτ takes two positive values of τ1\tau_{1}τ1​ and τ2>τ1\tau_{2}>\tau_{1}τ2​>τ1​ with equal probability. Then

τn‾=τ1n+τ2n2\begin{equation*} \overline{\tau^{n}}=\frac{\tau_{1}^{n}+\tau_{2}^{n}}{2} \tag{10.22} \end{equation*}τn=2τ1n​+τ2n​​​(10.22)​

and the generating function for the cumulants of the correlation function is

ln⁡τn‾=nln⁡τ1+ln⁡(1+(τ2/τ1)n2)=0nln⁡τ1+ln⁡(1+1+nln⁡(τ2/τ1)+n2/2ln⁡2(τ2/τ1)+⋯2)=nln⁡τ1+ln⁡[1+n2ln⁡(τ2τ1)+n24ln⁡2(τ2τ1)+⋯ ]=nln⁡τ1+n2ln⁡(τ2τ1)+n28ln⁡2(τ2τ1)+⋯=nln⁡(τ1τ2)+n28ln⁡2(τ2τ1)+⋯ .\begin{align*} \ln \overline{\tau^{n}} & =n \ln \tau_{1}+\ln \left(\frac{1+\left(\tau_{2} / \tau_{1}\right)^{n}}{2}\right) \\ & =0 n \ln \tau_{1}+\ln \left(\frac{1+1+n \ln \left(\tau_{2} / \tau_{1}\right)+n^{2} / 2 \ln ^{2}\left(\tau_{2} / \tau_{1}\right)+\cdots}{2}\right) \\ & =n \ln \tau_{1}+\ln \left[1+\frac{n}{2} \ln \left(\frac{\tau_{2}}{\tau_{1}}\right)+\frac{n^{2}}{4} \ln ^{2}\left(\frac{\tau_{2}}{\tau_{1}}\right)+\cdots\right] \tag{10.23}\\ & =n \ln \tau_{1}+\frac{n}{2} \ln \left(\frac{\tau_{2}}{\tau_{1}}\right)+\frac{n^{2}}{8} \ln ^{2}\left(\frac{\tau_{2}}{\tau_{1}}\right)+\cdots \\ & =n \ln \left(\sqrt{\tau_{1} \tau_{2}}\right)+\frac{n^{2}}{8} \ln ^{2}\left(\frac{\tau_{2}}{\tau_{1}}\right)+\cdots . \end{align*}lnτn​=nlnτ1​+ln(21+(τ2​/τ1​)n​)=0nlnτ1​+ln(21+1+nln(τ2​/τ1​)+n2/2ln2(τ2​/τ1​)+⋯​)=nlnτ1​+ln[1+2n​ln(τ1​τ2​​)+4n2​ln2(τ1​τ2​​)+⋯]=nlnτ1​+2n​ln(τ1​τ2​​)+8n2​ln2(τ1​τ2​​)+⋯=nln(τ1​τ2​​)+8n2​ln2(τ1​τ2​​)+⋯.​(10.23)​

Combining Eqs. (10.21) and (10.23), the cumulants of the correlation function are given by

{ln⁡⟨σ0σt⟩‾=tln⁡(τ1τ2)=a1tln⁡⟨σ0σt⟩c2‾=t4ln⁡2(τ2/τ1)=a2t⋮\left\{\begin{align*} \overline{\ln \left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle} & =t \ln \left(\sqrt{\tau_{1} \tau_{2}}\right)=a_{1} t \tag{10.24}\\ \overline{\ln \left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle_{c}^{2}} & =\frac{t}{4} \ln ^{2}\left(\tau_{2} / \tau_{1}\right)=a_{2} t \\ & \vdots \end{align*}\right.⎩⎨⎧​ln⟨σ0​σt​⟩​ln⟨σ0​σt​⟩c2​​​=tln(τ1​τ2​​)=a1​t=4t​ln2(τ2​/τ1​)=a2​t⋮​(10.24)​

While it is true that ln⁡⟨σ0σt⟩\ln \left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangleln⟨σ0​σt​⟩ is normally distributed for large ttt, and that characteristic function of a normal distribution is itself a Gaussian, we should be careful about the order of limits in terminating the power series in the exponent at the second order. If we do so, from

⟨σ0σt⟩n‾≈exp⁡[t(na1+n2a2/2)],\begin{equation*} \overline{\left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle^{n}} \approx \exp \left[t\left(n a_{1}+n^{2} a_{2} / 2\right)\right], \tag{10.25} \end{equation*}⟨σ0​σt​⟩n​≈exp[t(na1​+n2a2​/2)],​(10.25)​

we should not infer anything about the high moments (n→∞)(n \rightarrow \infty)(n→∞) and the tail of the distribution. Otherwise (since a2>0a_{2}>0a2​>0 ), we would conclude that sufficiently large moments of ⟨σ0σt⟩\left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle⟨σ0​σt​⟩ diverge with separation; a clearly false conclusion as ⟨σ0σt⟩\left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle⟨σ0​σt​⟩ is bounded by unity! The correct result is that

lim⁡n→∞⟨σ0σt⟩n‾=τ2nt2t,\begin{equation*} \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \overline{\left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangle^{n}}=\frac{\tau_{2}^{n t}}{2^{t}}, \tag{10.26} \end{equation*}n→∞lim​⟨σ0​σt​⟩n​=2tτ2nt​​,​(10.26)​

i.e. the high moments are almost entirely dominated by the one exceptional sample in which all bonds are equal to τ2\tau_{2}τ2​.

We can summarize the situation as follows: The "bulk" of the probability distribution for ln⁡⟨σ0σt⟩\ln \left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangleln⟨σ0​σt​⟩ is described by the small moments ( n→0n \rightarrow 0n→0 ), while the tail of the distribution is governed by the large moments (n→∞)(n \rightarrow \infty)(n→∞). We should have a clear idea of the crossover point n∗n^{*}n∗ in applying the replica method. For the above one dimensional example, an estimate of n∗n^{*}n∗ is given by the ratio of the successive terms in the expansion, i.e.

n∗=1ln⁡(τ2/τ1)\begin{equation*} n^{*}=\frac{1}{\ln \left(\tau_{2} / \tau_{1}\right)} \tag{10.27} \end{equation*}n∗=ln(τ2​/τ1​)1​​(10.27)​

Note that as τ2/τ1\tau_{2} / \tau_{1}τ2​/τ1​ becomes large, n∗n^{*}n∗ decreases, possibly becoming even smaller than unity. This does not imply that we should conclude that ln⁡⟨σ0σt⟩\ln \left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangleln⟨σ0​σt​⟩ is not normally distributed, just that the tail of the distribution is more prominent. Failure to appreciate this point is the source of some misunderstandings on the use of the replica method.

Clearly, it is possible to come up with many different microscopic distributions p(τ)p(\tau)p(τ), which result in the same first two cumulants in Eqs. (10.24), but different higher cumulants. All these cases lead to the same universal bulk probability distribution for ln⁡⟨σ0σt⟩\ln \left\langle\sigma_{0} \sigma_{t}\right\rangleln⟨σ0​σt​⟩ at large ttt, but very different tails. Thus the non-uniqueness of the overall probability in this example has to do with the rather uninteresting (and non-universal) behavior of the tail of the distribution. The correct interpretation of Eqs. (10.24) is that the mean value for the logarithm of the correlation function grows linearly with the separation ttt. In analogy with pure systems, we can regard the coefficient of this decay as the inverse correlation length, i.e. ξ−1=−ln⁡τ1τ2\xi^{-1}=-\ln \sqrt{\tau_{1} \tau_{2}}ξ−1=−lnτ1​τ2​​. However, due to randomness in the medium, correlations have different decays between different realizations (and between different points in the same realization). The variations in this "inverse correlation length" are scale dependent and fall off as 1/t1 / \sqrt{t}1/t​. In the next sections we shall attempt to generalize these results to higher dimensions.

10.4 Directed paths and the transfer matrix

Calculation of the correlation function in higher dimensions is complicated by the presence of an exponentially large number of paths connecting any pair of points. On physical grounds we expect the high temperature phase to be disordered, with correlations that decay exponentially as a function of the separation ttt. The essence of this exponential decay is captured by the lowest order terms in the high-temperature expansion. The first term in the series comes from the shortest path connecting the two points. Actually, along a generic direction on a hypercubic lattice there are many paths that have the same shortest length. (In two dimensions, the length of the shortest path connecting (0,0)(0,0)(0,0) to (t,x)(t, x)(t,x) is the "Manhattan" distance ∣t∣+∣x∣|t|+|x|∣t∣+∣x∣.) The number of paths grows from a minimum of 1 along a cardinal lattice direction to a maximum of ddd per step along the diagonal. (The number of paths on the square lattice is (t+x)!/(t!x!)(t+x)!/(t!x!)(t+x)!/(t!x!).) Thus the decay of correlations depends on orientation, a consequence of the anisotropy of the hypercubic lattice. (Note that this anisotropy is absent at distances less than the correlation length. We don't have to worry about anisotropy in discretizing critical (massless) theories on a lattice.)

In a uniform system these shortest paths are sufficient to capture the essence of correlation functions of the high-temperature phase: An exponential decay with separation which is generic to all spin systems with finite interactions. As temperature is reduced, more complicated paths (e.g. with loops and overhangs) start contributing to the sum. Although the contribution of these paths decays exponentially with their length, their number grows exponentially. Ultimately at the critical point this "entropic" increase in the number of paths overcomes the "energetic" decrease due to the factors of τ<1\tau<1τ<1, and paths of all length become important below TcT_{c}Tc​. However, throughout the high-temperature phase it is possible to examine the paths at a coarse-grained scale where no loops and overhangs are present. The scale of such structures is roughly the correlation length ξ\xiξ, and if we use ξ\xiξ as the unit of a coarse-grained lattice, the graphs contributing to the correlation function are directed paths.

Let us define "directed paths" more carefully: Between any pair of points on the lattice we can draw an imaginary line which can be regarded as a "time" axis ttt. Transverse directions (perpendicular to the ttt axis) are indicated by x⃗\vec{x}x.

Directed paths are similar to the world-lines of a particle x⃗(t)\vec{x}(t)x(t) in time; they exclude any path from the initial to the final point that has steps opposite to the main time direction. The validity of this approximation, and the importance of the neglected loops, must be carefully considered. It is certainly not valid in the vicinity of the critical point where loops of all sizes are present and equally important. Away from the critical point, we must distinguish between properties at scales smaller or larger than the correlation length ξ\xiξ. Limiting the sum for the correlation function to directed paths is only useful for separations t≫ξt \gg \xit≫ξ. Loops, overhangs, and additional structures occur up to size ξ\xiξ (the only relevant length scale) and can be removed by coarse graining such that the lattice spacing is larger than or equal to ξ\xiξ. This is automatically satisfied in a high-temperature expansion since the correlation length is zero at infinite temperature. By the same argument, we may also neglect the closed loops (vacuum bubbles) generated by the denominator of Eq. (10.9).

In the remainder of this section we shall recap how sums over directed paths in the uniform system can be calculated exactly by transfer matrix methods. The method is then generalized to random systems, providing an algorithm for summing all paths in polynomial time. For ease of visualization, let us first consider the problem in two dimensions; the results are easily generalizable to higher dimensions. Also to emphasize the general features of the transfer matrix method, we shall compare and contrast the behavior of correlations along the axis and the diagonal of the square lattice.

Fig. 10.1 A directed path along the principal axis of the square lattice.

To calculate the correlation function ⟨σ0,0σ0,t⟩\left\langle\sigma_{0,0} \sigma_{0, t}\right\rangle⟨σ0,0​σ0,t​⟩, on a non-random square lattice, we shall focus on directed paths oriented along the main axis of the square. These paths are specified by a set of transverse coordinates (x0,x1,x2,⋯ ,xt)\left(x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}, \cdots, x_{t}\right)(x0​,x1​,x2​,⋯,xt​), with x0=xt=0x_{0}=x_{t}=0x0​=xt​=0. Of course, there is only one shortest path with all xix_{i}xi​ equal to zero, but we would like to explore the corrections due to longer directed paths. Consider the set of quantities

⟨x,t∣W∣0,0⟩= sum over paths from (0,0) to (x,t)≡W(x,t).\begin{equation*} \langle x, t| W|0,0\rangle=\text { sum over paths from }(0,0) \text { to }(x, t) \equiv W(x, t) . \tag{10.28} \end{equation*}⟨x,t∣W∣0,0⟩= sum over paths from (0,0) to (x,t)≡W(x,t).​(10.28)​

The calculation of W(x,t)W(x, t)W(x,t) is easily accomplished by taking advantage of its Markovian property: Each step of a path proceeds from its last location and is independent of the previous steps. Hence WWW can be calculated recursively from,

W(x,t+1)=τ[W(x,t)+τ(W(x−1,t)+W(x+1,t))+O(τ2)]≡∑x′⟨x∣T∣x′⟩W(x′,t)\begin{align*} W(x, t+1) & =\tau\left[W(x, t)+\tau(W(x-1, t)+W(x+1, t))+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{2}\right)\right] \\ & \equiv \sum_{x^{\prime}}\langle x| T\left|x^{\prime}\right\rangle W\left(x^{\prime}, t\right) \tag{10.29} \end{align*}W(x,t+1)​=τ[W(x,t)+τ(W(x−1,t)+W(x+1,t))+O(τ2)]≡x′∑​⟨x∣T∣x′⟩W(x′,t)​(10.29)​

where we have introduced a transfer matrix,

⟨x∣T∣x′⟩=τδx,x′+τ2(δx,x′+1+δx,x′−1)+O(τ3)\begin{equation*} \langle x| T\left|x^{\prime}\right\rangle=\tau \delta_{x, x^{\prime}}+\tau^{2}\left(\delta_{x, x^{\prime}+1}+\delta_{x, x^{\prime}-1}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{3}\right) \tag{10.30} \end{equation*}⟨x∣T∣x′⟩=τδx,x′​+τ2(δx,x′+1​+δx,x′−1​)+O(τ3)​(10.30)​

If we treat the values of WWW at a particular ttt as a vector, Eq. (10.29) can be iterated as,

W‾(t)=TW‾(t−1)=⋯=TtW‾(0),\begin{equation*} \underline{W}(t)=T \underline{W}(t-1)=\cdots=T^{t} \underline{W}(0), \tag{10.31} \end{equation*}W​(t)=TW​(t−1)=⋯=TtW​(0),​(10.31)​

starting from

W‾(0)=(⋮τ1τ⋮)(10.32)\underline{W}(0)=\left(\begin{array}{c} \vdots \tag{10.32}\\ \tau \\ 1 \\ \tau \\ \vdots \end{array}\right)W​(0)=​⋮τ1τ⋮​​(10.32)

The calculations are simplified by diagonalizing the matrix TTT, using the Fourier basis ⟨x∣q⟩=eiq⋅x/N\langle x \mid q\rangle=\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q \cdot x} / \sqrt{N}⟨x∣q⟩=eiq⋅x/N​, as

T(q)=τ(1+2τcos⁡q+⋯ )=τexp⁡[2τ(1−q22+⋯ )]\begin{equation*} T(q)=\tau(1+2 \tau \cos q+\cdots)=\tau \exp \left[2 \tau\left(1-\frac{q^{2}}{2}+\cdots\right)\right] \tag{10.33} \end{equation*}T(q)=τ(1+2τcosq+⋯)=τexp[2τ(1−2q2​+⋯)]​(10.33)​

In this basis, WWW is calculated as

W(x,t)=⟨x∣Tt∣0⟩=∑q⟨x∣q⟩T(q)t⟨q∣0⟩=τte2τt∫ dq2πexp⁡[iqx−q2τt+⋯ ]=exp⁡[t(ln⁡τ+2τ+O(τ2))]×14πτtexp⁡[−x24τt].\begin{align*} W(x, t) & =\langle x| T^{t}|0\rangle=\sum_{q}\langle x \mid q\rangle T(q)^{t}\langle q \mid 0\rangle \\ & =\tau^{t} \mathrm{e}^{2 \tau t} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d} q}{2 \pi} \exp \left[\mathrm{i} q x-q^{2} \tau t+\cdots\right] \tag{10.34}\\ & =\exp \left[t\left(\ln \tau+2 \tau+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{2}\right)\right)\right] \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{4 \pi \tau t}} \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2}}{4 \tau t}\right] . \end{align*}W(x,t)​=⟨x∣Tt∣0⟩=q∑​⟨x∣q⟩T(q)t⟨q∣0⟩=τte2τt∫2π dq​exp[iqx−q2τt+⋯]=exp[t(lnτ+2τ+O(τ2))]×4πτt​1​exp[−4τtx2​].​(10.34)​

The result is proportional to a Gaussian form in xxx of width 2τt\sqrt{2 \tau t}2τt​. The exponential decay with ξ−1=ln⁡(1/τ)−2τ+O(τ2)\xi^{-1}=\ln (1 / \tau)-2 \tau+\mathcal{O}\left(\tau^{2}\right)ξ−1=ln(1/τ)−2τ+O(τ2) at x=0x=0x=0 is accompanied by a subleading 1/t1 / \sqrt{t}1/t​ reflecting the constraint to return to the origin.

The corresponding calculation for paths along the diagonal, contributing to ⟨σ0,0σ0,t⟩\left\langle\sigma_{0,0} \sigma_{0, t}\right\rangle⟨σ0,0​σ0,t​⟩ is even simpler. (Note that the ttt and xxx axes are rotated by 45∘45^{\circ}45∘ compared to the previous example.) At each step the path may proceed up or down, leading to the recursion relation

W(x,t+1)=τ(W(x−1,t)+W(x+1,t))≡∑x′⟨x∣T∣x′⟩W(x′,t),\begin{equation*} W(x, t+1)=\tau(W(x-1, t)+W(x+1, t)) \equiv \sum_{x^{\prime}}\langle x| T\left|x^{\prime}\right\rangle W\left(x^{\prime}, t\right), \tag{10.35} \end{equation*}W(x,t+1)=τ(W(x−1,t)+W(x+1,t))≡x′∑​⟨x∣T∣x′⟩W(x′,t),​(10.35)​

with the transfer matrix

⟨x∣T∣x′⟩=τ(δx,x′+1+δx,x′−1)⟹T(q)=2τcos⁡q.\begin{equation*} \langle x| T\left|x^{\prime}\right\rangle=\tau\left(\delta_{x, x^{\prime}+1}+\delta_{x, x^{\prime}-1}\right) \quad \Longrightarrow \quad T(q)=2 \tau \cos q . \tag{10.36} \end{equation*}⟨x∣T∣x′⟩=τ(δx,x′+1​+δx,x′−1​)⟹T(q)=2τcosq.​(10.36)​

The calculation of WWW proceeds as before,

W(x,t)=⟨x∣Tt∣0⟩=∑q⟨x∣q⟩T(q)t⟨q∣0⟩=∫dq2π(2τ)t(cos⁡q)teiqx≈(2τ)t×12πtexp⁡[−x22t],\begin{align*} W(x, t) & =\langle x| T^{t}|0\rangle=\sum_{q}\langle x \mid q\rangle T(q)^{t}\langle q \mid 0\rangle \\ & =\int \frac{\mathrm{d} q}{2 \pi}(2 \tau)^{t}(\cos q)^{t} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q x} \tag{10.37}\\ & \approx(2 \tau)^{t} \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi t}} \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2}}{2 t}\right], \end{align*}W(x,t)​=⟨x∣Tt∣0⟩=q∑​⟨x∣q⟩T(q)t⟨q∣0⟩=∫2πdq​(2τ)t(cosq)teiqx≈(2τ)t×2πt​1​exp[−2tx2​],​(10.37)​

where the final result is obtained by a saddle point evaluation of the integral, essentially replacing cos⁡tq\cos ^{t} qcostq with exp⁡(−q2t/2)\exp \left(-q^{2} t / 2\right)exp(−q2t/2).

The similarity between Eqs. (10.34) and (10.37) is apparent. Note that in both cases the leading exponential decay is determined by T(q=0)T(q=0)T(q=0), i.e.

W(0,t)≈λmax⁡t=T(q=0)t.\begin{equation*} W(0, t) \approx \lambda_{\max }^{t}=T(q=0)^{t} . \tag{10.38} \end{equation*}W(0,t)≈λmaxt​=T(q=0)t.​(10.38)​

Fig. 10.2 A directed path along the diagonal of the square lattice.

This is an example of the dominance of the largest eigenvalue in the product of a large number of matrices. There is a corresponding ground state dominance in the evolution of quantum systems. The similarities become further apparent by taking the continuum limit of the recursion relations, which are obtained by regarding W(x,t)W(x, t)W(x,t) as a smooth function, and expanding in the derivatives. From Eq. (10.29), we obtain

W+∂W∂t+⋯=τW+τ2(2W+∂2W∂x2+⋯ ),\begin{equation*} W+\frac{\partial W}{\partial t}+\cdots=\tau W+\tau^{2}\left(2 W+\frac{\partial^{2} W}{\partial x^{2}}+\cdots\right), \tag{10.39} \end{equation*}W+∂t∂W​+⋯=τW+τ2(2W+∂x2∂2W​+⋯),​(10.39)​

while Eq. (10.35) leads to

W+∂W∂t+⋯=2τW+τ∂2W∂x2+⋯\begin{equation*} W+\frac{\partial W}{\partial t}+\cdots=2 \tau W+\tau \frac{\partial^{2} W}{\partial x^{2}}+\cdots \tag{10.40} \end{equation*}W+∂t∂W​+⋯=2τW+τ∂x2∂2W​+⋯​(10.40)​

For large ttt, the function WWW decays slowly for adjacent points in the xxx direction, and it is justified to only consider the lowest order derivatives with respect to xxx. The decay factor along the ttt direction is, however, quite big and we shall keep track of all derivatives in this direction, leading to

e∂tW=τexp⁡[2τ+τ∂x2+⋯ ]W,\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{\partial_{t}} W=\tau \exp \left[2 \tau+\tau \partial_{x}^{2}+\cdots\right] W, \tag{10.41} \end{equation*}e∂t​W=τexp[2τ+τ∂x2​+⋯]W,​(10.41)​

and

e∂tW=2τexp⁡[12∂x2+⋯ ]W,\begin{equation*} \mathrm{e}^{\partial_{t}} W=2 \tau \exp \left[\frac{1}{2} \partial_{x}^{2}+\cdots\right] W, \tag{10.42} \end{equation*}e∂t​W=2τexp[21​∂x2​+⋯]W,​(10.42)​

respectively. Both equations can be rearranged (and generalized in higher dimensions) into the differential form,

∂W∂t=−Wξ(θ)+ν(θ)∇2W\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial W}{\partial t}=-\frac{W}{\xi(\theta)}+\nu(\theta) \nabla^{2} W \tag{10.43} \end{equation*}∂t∂W​=−ξ(θ)W​+ν(θ)∇2W​(10.43)​

where ξ(θ)\xi(\theta)ξ(θ) and ν(θ)\nu(\theta)ν(θ) are the orientation dependent correlation length and dispersion coefficient. Equation (10.43) can be regarded as a diffusion equation in the presence of a sink, or an imaginary-time Schrödinger equation.

It is of course quite easy to integrate this linear equation to reproduce the results in Eqs. (10.34) and (10.37) . However, it is also possible [R.P. Feynman and A.R. Hibbs, Quantum Mechanics and Path Integrals (McGraw-Hill, New York, 1965)] to express the solution in the form of a continuous path integral. The solution is trivial in Fourier space,

∂W(q)∂t=−(ξ−1+νq2)W⟹W(q,t+Δt)=e−(ξ−1+νq2)ΔtW(q,t)\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial W(q)}{\partial t}=-\left(\xi^{-1}+\nu q^{2}\right) W \quad \Longrightarrow \quad W(q, t+\Delta t)=\mathrm{e}^{-\left(\xi^{-1}+\nu q^{2}\right) \Delta t} W(q, t) \tag{10.44} \end{equation*}∂t∂W(q)​=−(ξ−1+νq2)W⟹W(q,t+Δt)=e−(ξ−1+νq2)ΔtW(q,t)​(10.44)​

while in real space,

W(x,t+Δt)=∫dq2πeiqxe−(ξ−1+νq2)ΔtW(q,t)=∫dq2πeiqxe(−ξ−1−νq2)Δt∫ dxte−iqxtW(xt,t)=∫dxtexp⁡[−Δtξ−(x−xt)24νΔt]W(xt,t)=∫dxtexp⁡[−Δtξ+Δt4ν(xt+Δt−xtΔt)2]W(xt,t)\begin{align*} W(x, t+\Delta t) & =\int \frac{\mathrm{d} q}{2 \pi} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q x} \mathrm{e}^{-\left(\xi^{-1}+\nu q^{2}\right) \Delta t} W(q, t) \\ & =\int \frac{\mathrm{d} q}{2 \pi} \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} q x} \mathrm{e}^{\left(-\xi^{-1}-\nu q^{2}\right) \Delta t} \int \mathrm{~d} x_{t} \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} q x_{t}} W\left(x_{t}, t\right) \\ & =\int \mathrm{d} x_{t} \exp \left[-\frac{\Delta t}{\xi}-\frac{\left(x-x_{t}\right)^{2}}{4 \nu \Delta t}\right] W\left(x_{t}, t\right) \tag{10.45}\\ & =\int \mathrm{d} x_{t} \exp \left[-\frac{\Delta t}{\xi}+\frac{\Delta t}{4 \nu}\left(\frac{x_{t+\Delta t}-x_{t}}{\Delta t}\right)^{2}\right] W\left(x_{t}, t\right) \end{align*}W(x,t+Δt)​=∫2πdq​eiqxe−(ξ−1+νq2)ΔtW(q,t)=∫2πdq​eiqxe(−ξ−1−νq2)Δt∫ dxt​e−iqxt​W(xt​,t)=∫dxt​exp[−ξΔt​−4νΔt(x−xt​)2​]W(xt​,t)=∫dxt​exp[−ξΔt​+4νΔt​(Δtxt+Δt​−xt​​)2]W(xt​,t)​(10.45)​

which is just a continuum version of Eqs. (10.29) and (10.35). We can subdivide the interval (0,t)(0, t)(0,t) into NNN subintervals of length Δt=t/N\Delta t=t / NΔt=t/N. In the limit of N→∞N \rightarrow \inftyN→∞, recursion of Eq. (10.45) gives

W(x,t)=∫(0.0)(x,t)Dx(t′)exp⁡[∫0t dt′(−1ξ(θ)−x˙24ν(θ))]\begin{equation*} W(x, t)=\int_{(0.0)}^{(x, t)} \mathcal{D} x\left(t^{\prime}\right) \exp \left[\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} t^{\prime}\left(-\frac{1}{\xi(\theta)}-\frac{\dot{x}^{2}}{4 \nu(\theta)}\right)\right] \tag{10.46} \end{equation*}W(x,t)=∫(0.0)(x,t)​Dx(t′)exp[∫0t​ dt′(−ξ(θ)1​−4ν(θ)x˙2​)]​(10.46)​

where x˙=dx/dt′\dot{x}=\mathrm{d} x / \mathrm{d} t^{\prime}x˙=dx/dt′, and the integration is over all functions x(t′)x\left(t^{\prime}\right)x(t′). It is instructive to compare the above path integral with the partition function of a string stretched between (0,0)(0,0)(0,0) and (x,t)(x, t)(x,t),

Z(x,t)=∫(0,0)(x,t)Dx(t′)exp⁡[−βσ∫0t dt′1+x˙2]=∫(0,0)(x,t)Dx(t′)exp⁡[−∫0t dt′(βσ+βσ2x˙2+⋯ )]\begin{align*} Z(x, t) & =\int_{(0,0)}^{(x, t)} \mathcal{D} x\left(t^{\prime}\right) \exp \left[-\beta \sigma \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} t^{\prime} \sqrt{1+\dot{x}^{2}}\right] \\ & =\int_{(0,0)}^{(x, t)} \mathcal{D} x\left(t^{\prime}\right) \exp \left[-\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} t^{\prime}\left(\beta \sigma+\frac{\beta \sigma}{2} \dot{x}^{2}+\cdots\right)\right] \tag{10.47} \end{align*}Z(x,t)​=∫(0,0)(x,t)​Dx(t′)exp[−βσ∫0t​ dt′1+x˙2​]=∫(0,0)(x,t)​Dx(t′)exp[−∫0t​ dt′(βσ+2βσ​x˙2+⋯)]​(10.47)​

where σ\sigmaσ is the line tension. Whereas for the string ξ−1=(2ν)−1=βσ\xi^{-1}=(2 \nu)^{-1}=\beta \sigmaξ−1=(2ν)−1=βσ, in general due to the anisotropy of the lattice these quantities need not be equal. By matching solutions at nearby angles of θ\thetaθ and θ+dθ\theta+\mathrm{d} \thetaθ+dθ, it is possible to obtain a relation between ξ−1(θ)\xi^{-1}(\theta)ξ−1(θ) and ν−1(θ)\nu^{-1}(\theta)ν−1(θ). (For a similar relation in the context of interfaces of Ising models, see [M.E. Fisher, J. Stat. Phys. 34, 667 (1984)]. However, ξ(θ)−1\xi(\theta)^{-1}ξ(θ)−1 calculated from the shortest paths only is singular along the axis θ=0\theta=0θ=0. This is why to calculate the parameter ν\nuν along this direction it is necessary to include longer directed paths.

10.5 Moments of the correlation function

We now return to the correlation functions in the presence of random bonds. In the high temperature limit, we can still set

W(x,t)≡⟨σ0,0σx,t⟩=∑P∏i=1tτPi\begin{equation*} W(x, t) \equiv\left\langle\sigma_{0,0} \sigma_{x, t}\right\rangle=\sum_{P} \prod_{i=1}^{t} \tau_{P i} \tag{10.48} \end{equation*}W(x,t)≡⟨σ0,0​σx,t​⟩=P∑​i=1∏t​τPi​​(10.48)​

where the sum is over all the diagonally oriented directed paths PPP from (0,0)(0,0)(0,0) to (x,t)(x, t)(x,t), and the τPi\tau_{P i}τPi​ denote factors of tanh⁡K\tanh KtanhK encountered for the random bonds along each path. The τi\tau_{i}τi​ are random variables, independently chosen for each bond. We shall assume that the probability distribution p(τ)p(\tau)p(τ) is narrowly distributed around a mean value τˉ\bar{\tau}τˉ with width σ\sigmaσ. Clearly, W(x,t)W(x, t)W(x,t) is itself a random variable and we would like to find its probability distribution. Rather than directly calculating p(W)p(W)p(W), we shall first examine its moments Wn‾\overline{W^{n}}Wn.

Calculation of the first moment is trivial: Each factor of τi\tau_{i}τi​ occurs at most once in Eq. (10.48), and hence after averaging,

W(x,t)‾≡⟨σ0,0σx,t⟩=∑Pτˉt.\begin{equation*} \overline{W(x, t)} \equiv\left\langle\sigma_{0,0} \sigma_{x, t}\right\rangle=\sum_{P} \bar{\tau}^{t} . \tag{10.49} \end{equation*}W(x,t)​≡⟨σ0,0​σx,t​⟩=P∑​τˉt.​(10.49)​

This is precisely the sum encountered in a non-random system, with τˉ\bar{\tau}τˉ replacing τ\tauτ. For example, along the square diagonal,

W(x,t)‾≈(2τˉ)t×12πtexp⁡[−x22t],\begin{equation*} \overline{W(x, t)} \approx(2 \bar{\tau})^{t} \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi t}} \exp \left[-\frac{x^{2}}{2 t}\right], \tag{10.50} \end{equation*}W(x,t)​≈(2τˉ)t×2πt​1​exp[−2tx2​],​(10.50)​

and in general, in the continuum limit,

∂Wˉ∂t=−Wˉξ+ν∂2Wˉ∂x2.\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial \bar{W}}{\partial t}=-\frac{\bar{W}}{\xi}+\nu \frac{\partial^{2} \bar{W}}{\partial x^{2}} . \tag{10.51} \end{equation*}∂t∂Wˉ​=−ξWˉ​+ν∂x2∂2Wˉ​.​(10.51)​

For the calculation of the second moment we need to evaluate

WW‾=∑P,P′∏i=1tτPiτP′i‾.\begin{equation*} \overline{W W}=\sum_{P, P^{\prime}} \prod_{i=1}^{t} \overline{\tau_{P i} \tau_{P^{\prime} i}} . \tag{10.52} \end{equation*}WW=P,P′∑​i=1∏t​τPi​τP′i​​.​(10.52)​

For a particular step iii, there are two possible averages depending on whether or not the two paths cross the same bond,

τPiτP′i‾={τˉ2 if Pi≠P′iτ2‾ if Pi=P′i(10.53)\overline{\tau_{P i} \tau_{P^{\prime} i}}= \begin{cases}\bar{\tau}^{2} & \text { if } P i \neq P^{\prime} i \tag{10.53}\\ \overline{\tau^{2}} & \text { if } P i=P^{\prime} i\end{cases}τPi​τP′i​​={τˉ2τ2​ if Pi=P′i if Pi=P′i​(10.53)

Since τ2‾>τˉ2\overline{\tau^{2}}>\bar{\tau}^{2}τ2>τˉ2 there is an enhanced weight favoring paths that intersect to those that don't. This can be regarded as an attraction between the two paths, represented by a Boltzmann weight,

U=τ2‾τˉ2=τˉ2+σ2τˉ2=1+σ2τˉ2≈eσ2/τˉ2\begin{equation*} U=\frac{\overline{\tau^{2}}}{\bar{\tau}^{2}}=\frac{\bar{\tau}^{2}+\sigma^{2}}{\bar{\tau}^{2}}=1+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\bar{\tau}^{2}} \approx \mathrm{e}^{\sigma^{2} / \bar{\tau}^{2}} \tag{10.54} \end{equation*}U=τˉ2τ2​=τˉ2τˉ2+σ2​=1+τˉ2σ2​≈eσ2/τˉ2​(10.54)​

Including this attraction, the recursion relation for WW‾\overline{W W}WW is,

W2(x1,x2,t)≡W(x1,t)W(x2,t)‾=∑x1′x2′⟨x1x2∣T2∣x1′x2′⟩W(x1′,x2′,t−1)\begin{equation*} W_{2}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, t\right) \equiv \overline{W\left(x_{1}, t\right) W\left(x_{2}, t\right)}=\sum_{x_{1}^{\prime} x_{2}^{\prime}}\left\langle x_{1} x_{2}\right| T_{2}\left|x_{1}^{\prime} x_{2}^{\prime}\right\rangle W\left(x_{1}^{\prime}, x_{2}^{\prime}, t-1\right) \tag{10.55} \end{equation*}W2​(x1​,x2​,t)≡W(x1​,t)W(x2​,t)​=x1′​x2′​∑​⟨x1​x2​∣T2​∣x1′​x2′​⟩W(x1′​,x2′​,t−1)​(10.55)​

with the two-body transfer matrix

⟨x1x2∣T2∣x1′x2′⟩=τˉ2(δx1,x1′+1+δx1,x1′−1)×(δx2,x2′+1x+δx2,x2′−1)(1+(U−1)δx1,x2δx1′,x2′).\begin{align*} \left\langle x_{1} x_{2}\right| T_{2}\left|x_{1}^{\prime} x_{2}^{\prime}\right\rangle= & \bar{\tau}^{2}\left(\delta_{x_{1}, x_{1}^{\prime}+1}+\delta_{x_{1}, x_{1}^{\prime}-1}\right) \tag{10.56}\\ & \times\left(\delta_{x_{2}, x_{2}^{\prime}+1} x+\delta_{x_{2}, x_{2}^{\prime}-1}\right)\left(1+(U-1) \delta_{x_{1}, x_{2}} \delta_{x_{1}^{\prime}, x_{2}^{\prime}}\right) . \end{align*}⟨x1​x2​∣T2​∣x1′​x2′​⟩=​τˉ2(δx1​,x1′​+1​+δx1​,x1′​−1​)×(δx2​,x2′​+1​x+δx2​,x2′​−1​)(1+(U−1)δx1​,x2​​δx1′​,x2′​​).​(10.56)​

The significance of the attraction in Eq. (10.54) is as follows. In the random system the paths prefer to pass through regions with particularly favorable values of τ\tauτ. After performing the average there are no preferred locations. The tendency for replicas of the original paths to bunch up at favorable spots is instead mimicked by the uniform attraction which tends to bundle together multiple paths representing the higher moments.

Fig. 10.3 A pair of paths (dashed and solid) contributing to calculation of the second moment of the sum over diagonally directed paths. The averaging over random bonds enhances the weight when the two paths cross the same bond.

In the continuum limit, Eq. (10.55) goes over to a differential equation of the form,

∂W2(x1,x2,t)∂t=−2W2ξ+ν∂2W2∂x12+ν∂2W2∂x22+uδ(x1−x2)W2≡−H2W2,\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial W_{2}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, t\right)}{\partial t}=-\frac{2 W_{2}}{\xi}+\nu \frac{\partial^{2} W_{2}}{\partial x_{1}^{2}}+\nu \frac{\partial^{2} W_{2}}{\partial x_{2}^{2}}+u \delta\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right) W_{2} \equiv-H_{2} W_{2}, \tag{10.57} \end{equation*}∂t∂W2​(x1​,x2​,t)​=−ξ2W2​​+ν∂x12​∂2W2​​+ν∂x22​∂2W2​​+uδ(x1​−x2​)W2​≡−H2​W2​,​(10.57)​

with u≈σ2/τˉ2u \approx \sigma^{2} / \bar{\tau}^{2}u≈σ2/τˉ2. Alternatively, we could have obtained Eq. (10.57) from the continuum version of the path integral,

W2(x1,x2,t)=∫(0.0)(x1,t)Dx1(t′)∫(0.0)(x2,t)Dx2(t′)exp⁡[∫0t dt′uδ(x1(t′)−x2(t′))]exp⁡[∫0t dt′(−1ξ−x˙124ν)]exp⁡[∫0t dt′(−1ξ−x˙224ν)].\begin{align*} W_{2}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, t\right)= & \int_{(0.0)}^{\left(x_{1}, t\right)} \mathcal{D} x_{1}\left(t^{\prime}\right) \int_{(0.0)}^{\left(x_{2}, t\right)} \mathcal{D} x_{2}\left(t^{\prime}\right) \exp \left[\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} t^{\prime} u \delta\left(x_{1}\left(t^{\prime}\right)-x_{2}\left(t^{\prime}\right)\right)\right] \\ & \exp \left[\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} t^{\prime}\left(-\frac{1}{\xi}-\frac{\dot{x}_{1}^{2}}{4 \nu}\right)\right] \exp \left[\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} t^{\prime}\left(-\frac{1}{\xi}-\frac{\dot{x}_{2}^{2}}{4 \nu}\right)\right] . \tag{10.58} \end{align*}W2​(x1​,x2​,t)=​∫(0.0)(x1​,t)​Dx1​(t′)∫(0.0)(x2​,t)​Dx2​(t′)exp[∫0t​ dt′uδ(x1​(t′)−x2​(t′))]exp[∫0t​ dt′(−ξ1​−4νx˙12​​)]exp[∫0t​ dt′(−ξ1​−4νx˙22​​)].​(10.58)​

Formally integrating Eq. (10.57) yields W2∝exp⁡(−tH2)W_{2} \propto \exp \left(-t H_{2}\right)W2​∝exp(−tH2​), which can be evaluated in the basis of eigenvalues of H2\mathrm{H}_{2}H2​ as

W2(x1,x2,t)=⟨x1x2∣T2t∣00⟩=∑m⟨x1x2∣m⟩e−ϵmt⟨m∣00⟩≈t→∞e−ε0t,\begin{equation*} W_{2}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}, t\right)=\left\langle x_{1} x_{2}\right| T_{2}^{t}|00\rangle=\sum_{m}\left\langle x_{1} x_{2} \mid m\right\rangle \mathrm{e}^{-\epsilon_{m} t}\langle m \mid 00\rangle \approx_{t \rightarrow \infty} \mathrm{e}^{-\varepsilon_{0} t}, \tag{10.59} \end{equation*}W2​(x1​,x2​,t)=⟨x1​x2​∣T2t​∣00⟩=m∑​⟨x1​x2​∣m⟩e−ϵm​t⟨m∣00⟩≈t→∞​e−ε0​t,​(10.59)​

where {εm}\left\{\varepsilon_{m}\right\}{εm​} are the eigenenergies of H2H_{2}H2​, regarded as a quantum Hamiltonian. The exponential growth of W2W_{2}W2​ for t→∞t \rightarrow \inftyt→∞ is dominated by the ground state "energy" of ε0\varepsilon_{0}ε0​.

The two-body Hamiltonian depends only on the relative separation of the two particles. After transforming to the center of mass coordinates,

{r=x1−x2R=(x1+x2)/2⟹∂12+∂22=12∂R2+2∂r2(10.60)\left\{\begin{array}{l} r=x_{1}-x_{2} \tag{10.60}\\ R=\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right) / 2 \end{array} \quad \Longrightarrow \quad \partial_{1}^{2}+\partial_{2}^{2}=\frac{1}{2} \partial_{R}^{2}+2 \partial_{r}^{2}\right.{r=x1​−x2​R=(x1​+x2​)/2​⟹∂12​+∂22​=21​∂R2​+2∂r2​(10.60)

the Hamiltonian reads,

H2=2ξ−ν2∂R2−2ν∂r2−uδ(r)\begin{equation*} H_{2}=\frac{2}{\xi}-\frac{\nu}{2} \partial_{R}^{2}-2 \nu \partial_{r}^{2}-u \delta(r) \tag{10.61} \end{equation*}H2​=ξ2​−2ν​∂R2​−2ν∂r2​−uδ(r)​(10.61)​

The relative coordinate describes a particle in a delta-function potential, which has a ground state wavefunction

ψ0(r,R)∝e−κ∣r∣\begin{equation*} \psi_{0}(r, R) \propto \mathrm{e}^{-\kappa|r|} \tag{10.62} \end{equation*}ψ0​(r,R)∝e−κ∣r∣​(10.62)​

The value of κ\kappaκ is obtained by integrating H2ψ0H_{2} \psi_{0}H2​ψ0​ from 0−0^{-}0−to 0+0^{+}0+, and requiring the discontinuity in the logarithmic derivative of ψ0\psi_{0}ψ0​ to match the strength of the potential; hence

−2ν(−κ−κ)=u⟹κ=u4ν≈σ22τˉ2\begin{equation*} -2 \nu(-\kappa-\kappa)=u \quad \Longrightarrow \quad \kappa=\frac{u}{4 \nu} \approx \frac{\sigma^{2}}{2 \bar{\tau}^{2}} \tag{10.63} \end{equation*}−2ν(−κ−κ)=u⟹κ=4νu​≈2τˉ2σ2​​(10.63)​

The ground state energy of this two particle system is

ε0=+2ξ−2νκ2≈2ξ−u28ν\begin{equation*} \varepsilon_{0}=+\frac{2}{\xi}-2 \nu \kappa^{2} \approx \frac{2}{\xi}-\frac{u^{2}}{8 \nu} \tag{10.64} \end{equation*}ε0​=+ξ2​−2νκ2≈ξ2​−8νu2​​(10.64)​

The inequality

W2(t)‾=exp⁡[−2tξ+u2t8ν]=W(t)‾2exp⁡(u2t8ν)≫W(t)‾2\begin{equation*} \overline{W^{2}(t)}=\exp \left[-\frac{2 t}{\xi}+\frac{u^{2} t}{8 \nu}\right]=\overline{W(t)}^{2} \exp \left(\frac{u^{2} t}{8 \nu}\right) \gg \overline{W(t)}^{2} \tag{10.65} \end{equation*}W2(t)​=exp[−ξ2t​+8νu2t​]=W(t)​2exp(8νu2t​)≫W(t)​2​(10.65)​

implies that the probability distribution for W(t)W(t)W(t) is quite broad, and becomes progressively wider distributed as t→∞t \rightarrow \inftyt→∞.

Higher moments of the sum are obtained from

Wn‾=∑P1,⋯ ,Pn∏i=1tτP1i⋯τPni‾.\begin{equation*} \overline{W^{n}}=\sum_{P_{1}, \cdots, P_{n}} \prod_{i=1}^{t} \overline{\tau_{P_{1} i} \cdots \tau_{P_{n} i}} . \tag{10.66} \end{equation*}Wn=P1​,⋯,Pn​∑​i=1∏t​τP1​i​⋯τPn​i​​.​(10.66)​

At a particular "time" slice there may or may not be intersections amongst the paths. Let us assume that τ\tauτ is Gaussian distributed with a mean τˉ\bar{\tau}τˉ, and a narrow width σ\sigmaσ; then,

τm‾≈∫ dxxm2πσ2exp⁡[−(x−τˉ)22σ2](set⁡x=τˉ+ϵ and expand in ϵ)≈∫dϵ2πσ2(τˉm+mτˉm−1ϵ+m(m−1)2τˉm−2ϵ2+⋯ )exp⁡[−ϵ22σ2]≈τˉm+m(m−1)2τˉm−2σ2+⋯≈τˉm(1+m(m−1)2σ2τˉ2+⋯ )≈τˉmexp⁡[m(m−1)2u]\begin{align*} \overline{\tau^{m}} & \approx \int \frac{\mathrm{~d} x x^{m}}{\sqrt{2 \pi \sigma^{2}}} \exp \left[-\frac{(x-\bar{\tau})^{2}}{2 \sigma^{2}}\right] \quad(\operatorname{set} x=\bar{\tau}+\epsilon \text { and expand in } \epsilon) \\ & \approx \int \frac{\mathrm{d} \epsilon}{\sqrt{2 \pi \sigma^{2}}}\left(\bar{\tau}^{m}+m \bar{\tau}^{m-1} \epsilon+\frac{m(m-1)}{2} \bar{\tau}^{m-2} \epsilon^{2}+\cdots\right) \exp \left[-\frac{\epsilon^{2}}{2 \sigma^{2}}\right] \\ & \approx \bar{\tau}^{m}+\frac{m(m-1)}{2} \bar{\tau}^{m-2} \sigma^{2}+\cdots \approx \bar{\tau}^{m}\left(1+\frac{m(m-1)}{2} \frac{\sigma^{2}}{\bar{\tau}^{2}}+\cdots\right) \\ & \approx \bar{\tau}^{m} \exp \left[\frac{m(m-1)}{2} u\right] \tag{10.67} \end{align*}τm​≈∫2πσ2​ dxxm​exp[−2σ2(x−τˉ)2​](setx=τˉ+ϵ and expand in ϵ)≈∫2πσ2​dϵ​(τˉm+mτˉm−1ϵ+2m(m−1)​τˉm−2ϵ2+⋯)exp[−2σ2ϵ2​]≈τˉm+2m(m−1)​τˉm−2σ2+⋯≈τˉm(1+2m(m−1)​τˉ2σ2​+⋯)≈τˉmexp[2m(m−1)​u]​(10.67)​

Since there are m(m−1)/2m(m-1) / 2m(m−1)/2 possibilities for pairing mmm particles, the above result represents the Boltzmann factor with a pairwise attraction of uuu for particles in contact. Since τ\tauτ is bounded by unity, the approximations leading to Eq. (10.67) must break down for sufficiently large mmm. This implies the presence of three and higher body interactions. Such interactions are usually of less importance at low densities and can be safely ignored. For a discussion of these higher order interactions in a similar context see [M. Lässig, Phys. Rev. Lett. 73, 561 (1994)].

The continuum version of the resulting path integral is

Wn(x1,⋯ ,xn,t)≡W(x1,t)⋯W(xn,t)‾=∫(0,0,⋯ ,0)(x1,⋯ ,xn,t)Dx1(t′)⋯Dxn(t′)exp⁡[−ntξ−∫0t dt′(∑αx˙α24ν−u2∑α≠βδ(xα(t′)−xβ(t′)))],\begin{align*} & W_{n}\left(x_{1}, \cdots, x_{n}, t\right) \equiv \overline{W\left(x_{1}, t\right) \cdots W\left(x_{n}, t\right)}=\int_{(0,0, \cdots, 0)}^{\left(x_{1}, \cdots, x_{n}, t\right)} \mathcal{D} x_{1}\left(t^{\prime}\right) \cdots \mathcal{D} x_{n}\left(t^{\prime}\right) \\ & \exp \left[-\frac{n t}{\xi}-\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} t^{\prime}\left(\sum_{\alpha} \frac{\dot{x}_{\alpha}^{2}}{4 \nu}-\frac{u}{2} \sum_{\alpha \neq \beta} \delta\left(x_{\alpha}\left(t^{\prime}\right)-x_{\beta}\left(t^{\prime}\right)\right)\right)\right], \tag{10.68} \end{align*}​Wn​(x1​,⋯,xn​,t)≡W(x1​,t)⋯W(xn​,t)​=∫(0,0,⋯,0)(x1​,⋯,xn​,t)​Dx1​(t′)⋯Dxn​(t′)exp​−ξnt​−∫0t​ dt′​α∑​4νx˙α2​​−2u​α=β∑​δ(xα​(t′)−xβ​(t′))​​,​(10.68)​

and evolves according to

∂Wn∂t=−nWnξ+ν∑α=1n∂2Wn∂xα2+u2∑α≠βδ(xα(τ)−xβ(τ))Wn≡−HnWn.\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial W_{n}}{\partial t}=-\frac{n W_{n}}{\xi}+\nu \sum_{\alpha=1}^{n} \frac{\partial^{2} W_{n}}{\partial x_{\alpha}^{2}}+\frac{u}{2} \sum_{\alpha \neq \beta} \delta\left(x_{\alpha}(\tau)-x_{\beta}(\tau)\right) W_{n} \equiv-H_{n} W_{n} . \tag{10.69} \end{equation*}∂t∂Wn​​=−ξnWn​​+να=1∑n​∂xα2​∂2Wn​​+2u​α=β∑​δ(xα​(τ)−xβ​(τ))Wn​≡−Hn​Wn​.​(10.69)​

The asymptotic behavior of WnW_{n}Wn​ at large ttt is controlled by the ground state of HnH_{n}Hn​. The corresponding wavefunction is obtained by a simple Bethe Ansatz [H.B. Thacker, Rev. Mod. Phys. 53, 253 (1981)] which generalizes Eq. (10.62) to

ψ0(x1,⋯ ,xn)∝exp⁡[−κ2∑α≠β∣xα−xβ∣] with κ=u4ν. \begin{equation*} \psi_{0}\left(x_{1}, \cdots, x_{n}\right) \propto \exp \left[-\frac{\kappa}{2} \sum_{\alpha \neq \beta}\left|x_{\alpha}-x_{\beta}\right|\right] \text { with } \kappa=\frac{u}{4 \nu} \text {. } \tag{10.70} \end{equation*}ψ0​(x1​,⋯,xn​)∝exp​−2κ​α=β∑​∣xα​−xβ​∣​ with κ=4νu​. ​(10.70)​

For each ordering of particles on the line, the wave function can be written as a product of exponentials ψ0∝exp⁡[καxα]\psi_{0} \propto \exp \left[\kappa_{\alpha} x_{\alpha}\right]ψ0​∝exp[κα​xα​], with the "momenta" κα\kappa_{\alpha}κα​ getting permuted for different orderings. For example, if x1<x2<⋯<xnx_{1}<x_{2}<\cdots<x_{n}x1​<x2​<⋯<xn​, the momenta are

κα=κ[2α−(n+1)],\kappa_{\alpha}=\kappa[2 \alpha-(n+1)],κα​=κ[2α−(n+1)],

Fig. 10.4 A configuration of four paths with attraction upon contact. forming a so-called nnn-string. The kinetic energy is proportional to

S=∑α=1n[2α−(n+1)]2=∑α=1n[(n+1)2−4α(n+1)+4α2]=n(n+1)2−4(n+1)⋅n(n+1)2+4n(n+1)(2n+1)6=n(n+1)[−(n+1)+2(2n+1)3]=n(n+1)(n−1)3\begin{align*} S & =\sum_{\alpha=1}^{n}[2 \alpha-(n+1)]^{2}=\sum_{\alpha=1}^{n}\left[(n+1)^{2}-4 \alpha(n+1)+4 \alpha^{2}\right] \\ & =n(n+1)^{2}-4(n+1) \cdot \frac{n(n+1)}{2}+\frac{4 n(n+1)(2 n+1)}{6} \tag{10.72}\\ & =n(n+1)\left[-(n+1)+\frac{2(2 n+1)}{3}\right]=\frac{n(n+1)(n-1)}{3} \end{align*}S​=α=1∑n​[2α−(n+1)]2=α=1∑n​[(n+1)2−4α(n+1)+4α2]=n(n+1)2−4(n+1)⋅2n(n+1)​+64n(n+1)(2n+1)​=n(n+1)[−(n+1)+32(2n+1)​]=3n(n+1)(n−1)​​(10.72)​

leading to the ground state energy

ε0=nξ−ν∑α=1nκα2=nξ−νκ23n(n2−1).\begin{equation*} \varepsilon_{0}=\frac{n}{\xi}-\nu \sum_{\alpha=1}^{n} \kappa_{\alpha}^{2}=\frac{n}{\xi}-\frac{\nu \kappa^{2}}{3} n\left(n^{2}-1\right) . \tag{10.73} \end{equation*}ε0​=ξn​−να=1∑n​κα2​=ξn​−3νκ2​n(n2−1).​(10.73)​

Thus the asymptotic behavior of moments of the sum has the form

lim⁡t→∞Wn(t)‾=exp⁡[−ntξ+n(n2−1)νκ2t3]=W(t)n‾exp⁡(n(n2−1)u2t48ν).\begin{equation*} \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} \overline{W^{n}(t)}=\exp \left[-\frac{n t}{\xi}+\frac{n\left(n^{2}-1\right) \nu \kappa^{2} t}{3}\right]=\overline{W(t)^{n}} \exp \left(\frac{n\left(n^{2}-1\right) u^{2} t}{48 \nu}\right) . \tag{10.74} \end{equation*}t→∞lim​Wn(t)​=exp[−ξnt​+3n(n2−1)νκ2t​]=W(t)n​exp(48νn(n2−1)u2t​).​(10.74)​

10.6 The probability distribution in two dimensions

It is tempting to use Eq. (10.74) in conjunction with

lim⁡n→0ln⁡(Wn(t)‾)=nln⁡W‾+n22(ln⁡W)c2‾+⋯+npp!ln⁡W)cp‾+⋯ ,\begin{equation*} \lim _{n \rightarrow 0} \ln \left(\overline{W^{n}(t)}\right)=n \overline{\ln W}+\frac{n^{2}}{2} \overline{(\ln W)_{c}^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{n^{p}}{p!} \overline{\ln W)_{c}^{p}}+\cdots, \tag{10.75} \end{equation*}n→0lim​ln(Wn(t)​)=nlnW+2n2​(lnW)c2​​+⋯+p!np​lnW)cp​​+⋯,​(10.75)​

to read off the cumulants for the probability distribution for ln⁡W\ln WlnW. The key point is the absence of the n2n^{2}n2 term and the presence of the n3tn^{3} tn3t factor in the exponent of Eq. (10.74), suggesting a third cumulant, and hence fluctuations in ln⁡W\ln WlnW that grow as t1/3t^{1 / 3}t1/3 [M. Kardar, Nucl. Phys. B 290, 582 (1987)]. However, as discussed before, there are subtleties in trying to deduce a probability distribution from the knowledge of its moments which we need to consider first. Since W(t)W(t)W(t) is bounded by unity, Eq. (10.74) cannot be valid for arbitrarily large nnn. Our first task is to identify the crossover point n∗n^{*}n∗ beyond which this result is no longer correct.

Equation (10.73) is obtained for the ground state of nnn particles subject to a two body interaction in the continuum limit. A simple argument can be used to understand the origin of the n3n^{3}n3 term in the energy, as well as the limitations of the continuum approach. Let us assume that the nnn particles form a bound state of size RRR. For large nnn, the energy of such a state can be estimated as

ε≈nξ+νnR2−un2R.\begin{equation*} \varepsilon \approx \frac{n}{\xi}+\frac{\nu n}{R^{2}}-\frac{u n^{2}}{R} . \tag{10.76} \end{equation*}ε≈ξn​+R2νn​−Run2​.​(10.76)​

A variational estimate is obtained by minimizing the above expression with respect to RRR, resulting in R∝ν/(un)R \propto \nu /(u n)R∝ν/(un) and ε∝u2n3/ν\varepsilon \propto u^{2} n^{3} / \nuε∝u2n3/ν. The size of the bound state decreases with increasing nnn, and the continuum approximation breaks down when it becomes of the order of the lattice spacing for n∗∝ν/u≈τˉ2/σ2n^{*} \propto \nu / u \approx \bar{\tau}^{2} / \sigma^{2}n∗∝ν/u≈τˉ2/σ2. For n≫n∗n \gg n^{*}n≫n∗ all the paths collapse together and

lim⁡n→∞Wn(t)‾≃(2τn‾)t.\begin{equation*} \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \overline{W^{n}(t)} \simeq\left(2 \overline{\tau^{n}}\right)^{t} . \tag{10.77} \end{equation*}n→∞lim​Wn(t)​≃(2τn)t.​(10.77)​

This asymptotic behavior is non-universal and depends on the extreme values of the local probability distribution for τ\tauτ. Depending on the choice of parameters, n∗n^{*}n∗ can be large or small. However, as discussed in the context of the one dimensional problem, its value controls only the relative importance of the tail and the bulk of the probability distribution for ln⁡W\ln WlnW. The behavior of the bulk of the distribution is expected to be universal. The crossover at n∗n^{*}n∗ is explicitly demonstrated in a related model in [E. Medina and M. Kardar, J. Stat. Phys. 71, 967 (1992)].

Another important consideration is the order of limits. Equation (10.74) is obtained by taking the t→∞t \rightarrow \inftyt→∞ limit at fixed nnn, while the cumulant series in Eq. (10.75) relies on an expansion around n→0n \rightarrow 0n→0 for fixed ttt. The two limits do not commute. In fact, we would naively deduce from Eq. (10.74) that only the third cumulant of ln⁡W\ln WlnW is non-zero. This is incorrect as it is impossible to have a probability distribution with only a third cumulant [W. Feller, An Introduction to Probability Theory and its Applications(Wiley, 1971)]. The correct procedure [E. Medina and M. Kardar, J. Stat. Phys. 71, 967 (1992)] is to assume that the singular behavior associated with n→0n \rightarrow 0n→0 and t→∞t \rightarrow \inftyt→∞ is described by a scaling function of the form gs(ntω)g_{s}\left(n t^{\omega}\right)gs​(ntω). (This is similar to a singular form at a critical point with nnn behaving as a relevant operator with scaling exponent of ω\omegaω.) If t→∞t \rightarrow \inftyt→∞ at fixed nnn, extensivity of the free energy of the nnn particle system forces ln⁡Wn(t)‾\ln \overline{W^{n}(t)}lnWn(t)​ to be proportional to ttt. At the other limit of n→0n \rightarrow 0n→0 at fixed ttt, the result is a power series in nnn, i.e.

ln⁡Wn(t)‾=ant+gs(ntω)={ant+ρn1/ωt for t→∞ at fixed nant+g1ntω+g2(ntω)2+⋯ for fixed t as n→0(10.78)\ln \overline{W^{n}(t)}=a n t+g_{s}\left(n t^{\omega}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{l} a n t+\rho n^{1 / \omega} t \quad \text { for } t \rightarrow \infty \text { at fixed } n \tag{10.78}\\ a n t+g_{1} n t^{\omega}+g_{2}\left(n t^{\omega}\right)^{2}+\cdots \text { for fixed } t \text { as } n \rightarrow 0 \end{array}\right.lnWn(t)​=ant+gs​(ntω)={ant+ρn1/ωt for t→∞ at fixed nant+g1​ntω+g2​(ntω)2+⋯ for fixed t as n→0​(10.78)

(Note the inclusion of a non-singular term, ant.) Similar considerations have been put forward in [R. Friedberg and Y.-K. Yu, Phys. Rev. E 49, 4157 (1994)]. Comparison with Eq. (10.74) gives ω=1/3\omega=1 / 3ω=1/3, and we can read off the cumulants of ln⁡W\ln WlnW as

{ln⁡W(t)‾=at+g1t1/3ln⁡W2(t)c‾=2g2t2/3⋮ln⁡Wp(t)c‾=p!gptp/3\left\{\begin{align*} \overline{\ln W(t)} & =a t+g_{1} t^{1 / 3} \tag{10.79}\\ \overline{\ln W^{2}(t)_{c}} & =2 g_{2} t^{2 / 3} \\ & \vdots \\ \overline{\ln W^{p}(t)_{c}} & =p!g_{p} t^{p / 3} \end{align*}\right.⎩⎨⎧​lnW(t)​lnW2(t)c​​lnWp(t)c​​​=at+g1​t1/3=2g2​t2/3⋮=p!gp​tp/3​(10.79)​

The existence of t1/3t^{1 / 3}t1/3 corrections to the quench averaged value of ln⁡W(t)\ln W(t)lnW(t) was first proposed by Bouchaud and Orland [J.-P. Bouchaud and H. Orland, J. Stat. Phys. 61, 877 (1990)] and has been numerically verified [E. Medina and M. Kardar, Phys. Rev. B 46, 9984 (1992)]. The t2/3t^{2 / 3}t2/3 growth of the variance of the probability distribution was obtained by Huse and Henley [D.A. Huse and C.L. Henley, Phys. Rev. Lett. 54, 2708 (1985)] in the context of interfaces of Ising models at zero temperature where an optimal path dominates the sum. The results remain valid at finite temperatures [M. Kardar, Phys. Rev. Lett. 55,

2923 (1985)]. Simulations are performed by implementing the transfer matrix method numerically. For example, along the diagonal of the square lattice, the recursion relation

W(x,t+1)=τx,t,−W(x−1,t)+τx,t,+W(x+1,t),\begin{equation*} W(x, t+1)=\tau_{x, t,-} W(x-1, t)+\tau_{x, t,+} W(x+1, t), \tag{10.80} \end{equation*}W(x,t+1)=τx,t,−​W(x−1,t)+τx,t,+​W(x+1,t),​(10.80)​

is iterated starting from W(x,0)=δx,0W(x, 0)=\delta_{x, 0}W(x,0)=δx,0​. The random numbers τx,t,σ\tau_{x, t, \sigma}τx,t,σ​ are generated as the iteration proceeds. The memory requirement (the arrays W(x)W(x)W(x) ) depend on the final length ttt; each update requires ttt operations, and the total execution time grows as t2t^{2}t2. Thus for a given realization of randomness, exact results are obtained in polynomial time. Of course the results have to be averaged over many realizations of randomness. The typical values of ttt used in the transfer matrix simulations range from 10310^{3}103 to 10410^{4}104, with 10210^{2}102 to 10310^{3}103 realizations. Calculating higher cumulants becomes progressively more difficult. The existence of the third cumulant was verified by Halpin-Healy [J. Krug, P. Meakin and T. Halpin-Healy, Phys. Rev. A, 45638 (1992)]. A fourth cumulant, growing as t4/3t^{4 / 3}t4/3 was observed by Kim et al. [J.M. Kim, M.A. Moore, and A.J. Bray, Phys. Rev. A 44, 2345 (1991)]. Starting from the replica result, Zhang [Y.-C. Zhang, Phys. Rev. Lett. 62, 979 (1989); Europhys. Lett. 9, 113 (1989); J. Stat. Phys. 57, 1123 (1989)] proposed an analytical form, p(ln⁡W,t)∼p(\ln W, t) \simp(lnW,t)∼ exp⁡(−a∣ln⁡W−ln⁡W‾∣3/2/t1/2)\exp \left(-a|\ln W-\overline{\ln W}|^{3 / 2} / t^{1 / 2}\right)exp(−a∣lnW−lnW∣3/2/t1/2). While this form captures the correct scaling of free energy fluctuations, it is symmetric about the average value precluding the observed finite third cumulant. This deficiency was remedied by Crisanti et al. [A. Crisanti, G. Paladin, H.-J. Sommers, and A. Vulpiani, J. Phys. I (France) 2, 1325 (1992)] who generalized the above probability to one with different coefficients a±a_{ \pm}a±​on the two sides of the mean value.

So far, we have focused on the asymptotic behavior of W(x,t)W(x, t)W(x,t) at large ttt, ignoring the dependence on the transverse coordinate. For the pure problem, the dependence of WWW on the transverse coordinate is a Gaussian, centered at the origin, with a width that grows as t1/2t^{1 / 2}t1/2. The full dependence is obtained in the non-random case by including the band of eigenvalues with energies close to the ground state. Unfortunately, determining the appropriate eigenvalues for the interacting problem is rather difficult. In addition to the eigenvalues obtained by simply multiplying Eq. (10.70) by exp⁡[iq(x1+⋯+xn)]\exp \left[\mathrm{i} q\left(x_{1}+\cdots+x_{n}\right)\right]exp[iq(x1​+⋯+xn​)], there are other states with broken replica symmetry [G. Parisi, J. Physique (France) 51, 1595 (1990)]. A treatment by Bouchaud and Orland [J.-P. Bouchaud and H. Orland, J. Stat. Phys. 61, 877 (1990)] includes some of the effects of such excitations but is not fully rigorous. It does predict that the extent of transverse fluctuations grows as tζt^{\zeta}tζ with ζ=2/3\zeta=2 / 3ζ=2/3 as observed numerically [D.A. Huse and C.L. Henley, Phys. Rev. Lett. 54, 2708 (1985)] [M. Kardar, Phys. Rev. Lett. 55, 2923 (1985)]. There is in fact a relation between the exponents ζ\zetaζ and ω\omegaω which follows from simple physical considerations: By analogy with a string, the energy to stretch a path by a distance xxx grows as x2/tx^{2} / tx2/t. The path wanders away from the origin, only if the cost of this stretching can be made up by favorable configurations of bonds. Since the typical fluctuations in (free) energy at scale ttt grow as tωt^{\omega}tω, we have

x2t∝tω⟹ω=2ζ−1\begin{equation*} \frac{x^{2}}{t} \propto t^{\omega} \quad \Longrightarrow \quad \omega=2 \zeta-1 \tag{10.81} \end{equation*}tx2​∝tω⟹ω=2ζ−1​(10.81)​

This relation remains valid in higher dimensions and has been verified in many numerical simulations. The first (indirect) proof of ω=1/3\omega=1 / 3ω=1/3 was based on a replica analysis of a problem with many interacting paths [M. Kardar and D.R. Nelson, Phys. Rev. Lett. 55, 1157 (1985)]. It was soon followed by a more direct proof [D.A. Huse, C.L. Henley, and D.S. Fisher, Phys. Rev. Lett. 55, 2924 (1985)] based on a completely different approach: the Cole-Hopf transformation and the mapping to the interface problem (see below) described in the previous chapter.

10.7 Higher dimensions

The approach described in the previous sections is easily generalized to higher dimensions. The directed path in d=D+1d=D+1d=D+1 is described by x⃗(t)\vec{x}(t)x(t), where x⃗\vec{x}x is a DDD-dimensional vector. Along a diagonal, Eq. (10.80) is generalized to

W(x⃗,t+1)=∑i=1dτx⃗−e⃗i,tW(x⃗−e⃗i,t)\begin{equation*} W(\vec{x}, t+1)=\sum_{i=1}^{d} \tau_{\vec{x}-\vec{e}_{i}, t} W\left(\vec{x}-\vec{e}_{i}, t\right) \tag{10.82} \end{equation*}W(x,t+1)=i=1∑d​τx−ei​,t​W(x−ei​,t)​(10.82)​

where e⃗i\vec{e}_{i}ei​ are unit vectors. The recursion relation is easily iterated on a computer, but the memory requirement and execution time now grow as tDt^{D}tD and tD+1t^{D+1}tD+1, respectively. The continuum limit of this recursion relation is

∂W(x⃗,t)∂t=−Wξ+ν∇2W+μ(x⃗,t)W\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial W(\vec{x}, t)}{\partial t}=-\frac{W}{\xi}+\nu \nabla^{2} W+\mu(\vec{x}, t) W \tag{10.83} \end{equation*}∂t∂W(x,t)​=−ξW​+ν∇2W+μ(x,t)W​(10.83)​

where μ(x⃗,t)\mu(\vec{x}, t)μ(x,t) represents the fluctuations of τ(x⃗,t)\tau(\vec{x}, t)τ(x,t) around its average. Thus it has zero mean, and a variance

μ(x⃗,t)μ(x⃗′,t′)‾=σ2δD(x⃗−x⃗′)δ(t−t′)\begin{equation*} \overline{\mu(\vec{x}, t) \mu\left(\vec{x}^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)}=\sigma^{2} \delta^{D}\left(\vec{x}-\vec{x}^{\prime}\right) \delta\left(t-t^{\prime}\right) \tag{10.84} \end{equation*}μ(x,t)μ(x′,t′)​=σ2δD(x−x′)δ(t−t′)​(10.84)​

(In a more general anisotropic situation, Eq. (10.83) has to be generalized to include different diffusivities να\nu_{\alpha}να​ along different directions. Such anisotropy is easily removed by rescaling the coordinates xαx_{\alpha}xα​.)

Equation (10.83) can be regarded as the imaginary time Schrödinger equation for a particle in a random time dependent potential. It can be integrated to yield the continuous path integral

W(x⃗,t)=∫(0,0)(x⃗,t)Dx⃗(t′)exp⁡[−∫0t dt′(1ξ+x⃗˙24ν−μ(x⃗(t′),t′))]\begin{equation*} W(\vec{x}, t)=\int_{(0,0)}^{(\vec{x}, t)} \mathcal{D} \vec{x}\left(t^{\prime}\right) \exp \left[-\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} t^{\prime}\left(\frac{1}{\xi}+\frac{\dot{\vec{x}}^{2}}{4 \nu}-\mu\left(\vec{x}\left(t^{\prime}\right), t^{\prime}\right)\right)\right] \tag{10.85} \end{equation*}W(x,t)=∫(0,0)(x,t)​Dx(t′)exp[−∫0t​ dt′(ξ1​+4νx˙2​−μ(x(t′),t′))]​(10.85)​

describing the fluctuations of a directed polymer in a random medium (DPRM) [M. Kardar and Y.-C. Zhang, Phys. Rev. Lett. 58, 2087 (1987)]. The nnnth moment of WWW is computed by replicating the above path integral and averaging over μ(x⃗,t)\mu(\vec{x}, t)μ(x,t). This generalizes Eq. (10.58) to

Wn({x⃗α},t)=∫({0→},0)({x⃗α},t)Dx⃗1(t′)⋯Dx⃗n(t′)exp⁡[−∫0t dt′(∑α1ξ+x⃗˙α24ν−u2∑α≠βδD(x⃗α(t′)−x⃗β(t′)))]\begin{align*} W_{n}\left(\left\{\vec{x}_{\alpha}\right\}, t\right)= & \int_{(\{\overrightarrow{0}\}, 0)}^{\left(\left\{\vec{x}_{\alpha}\right\}, t\right)} \mathcal{D} \vec{x}_{1}\left(t^{\prime}\right) \cdots \mathcal{D} \vec{x}_{n}\left(t^{\prime}\right) \\ & \exp \left[-\int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} t^{\prime}\left(\sum_{\alpha} \frac{1}{\xi}+\frac{\dot{\vec{x}}_{\alpha}^{2}}{4 \nu}-\frac{u}{2} \sum_{\alpha \neq \beta} \delta^{D}\left(\vec{x}_{\alpha}\left(t^{\prime}\right)-\vec{x}_{\beta}\left(t^{\prime}\right)\right)\right)\right] \tag{10.86} \end{align*}Wn​({xα​},t)=​∫({0},0)({xα​},t)​Dx1​(t′)⋯Dxn​(t′)exp​−∫0t​ dt′​α∑​ξ1​+4νx˙α2​​−2u​α=β∑​δD(xα​(t′)−xβ​(t′))​​​(10.86)​

with u∝σ2u \propto \sigma^{2}u∝σ2. The differential equation governing the evolution of Wn(t)W_{n}(t)Wn​(t) is,

∂Wn∂t=−nξWn+ν∑α∇α2Wn+u2∑α≠βδD(x⃗α−x⃗β)Wn≡−HnWn.\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial W_{n}}{\partial t}=-\frac{n}{\xi} W_{n}+\nu \sum_{\alpha} \nabla_{\alpha}^{2} W_{n}+\frac{u}{2} \sum_{\alpha \neq \beta} \delta^{D}\left(\vec{x}_{\alpha}-\vec{x}_{\beta}\right) W_{n} \equiv-H_{n} W_{n} . \tag{10.87} \end{equation*}∂t∂Wn​​=−ξn​Wn​+να∑​∇α2​Wn​+2u​α=β∑​δD(xα​−xβ​)Wn​≡−Hn​Wn​.​(10.87)​

Evaluating the asymptotic behavior of Wn(t)W_{n}(t)Wn​(t) requires knowledge of the ground state energy of the Hamiltonian HnH_{n}Hn​. Unfortunately, the exact dependence of the bound state energy on nnn is known only for D=0(ε∝n(n−1))D=0(\varepsilon \propto n(n-1))D=0(ε∝n(n−1)) and D=1(ε∝n(n2−1))D=1\left(\varepsilon \propto n\left(n^{2}-1\right)\right)D=1(ε∝n(n2−1)). As discussed earlier, these two results can then be used to deduce the behavior of the bulk of the probability distribution for ln⁡W(t)\ln W(t)lnW(t). Elementary results from quantum mechanics tell us that an arbitrarily small attraction leads to the formation of a bound state in D≤2D \leq 2D≤2, but that a finite strength of the potential is needed to form a bound state in D>2D>2D>2. Thus, in the most interesting case of 2+12+12+1 dimensions we expect a non-trivial probability distribution, while the replica method provides no information on its behavior. In higher dimensions, there is a phase transition between weak and strong randomness regimes. For weak randomness there is no bound state and asymptotically Wn(t)‾=W(t)n‾\overline{W^{n}(t)}=\overline{W(t)^{n}}Wn(t)​=W(t)n​, indicating a sharp probability distribution. This statement has also been established by more rigorous methods [J. Imbrie and T. Spencer, J. Stat. Phys. 52, 609 (1988)]. There is another phase for strong randomness where the probability distribution for W(t)W(t)W(t) becomes broad. The resulting bound state has been analytically studied in a 1/D1 / D1/D expansion valid for large DDD [Y.Y. Goldschmidt, Nucl. Phys. B 393, 507 (1993)]. The ground state wavefunction is rather complex, involving replica symmetry breaking. Note that the phase transition in the probability distribution of the correlation function occurs in the high-temperature phase of the random bond Ising model. The implications of this phase transition for bulk properties are not known. As the stiffness associated with line tension decreases on approaching the order/disorder phase transition of the Ising model, close to this transition the probability distribution for W(t)W(t)W(t) is likely to be broad.

As one of the simplest models of statistical mechanics in random systems (a "toy" spin glass), the problem of DPRM has been rather extensively studied [D.S. Fisher and D.A. Huse, Phys. Rev. B 43, 10728 (1991)]. The model has been generalized to manifolds of arbitrary internal dimensions in random media [T. Halpin-Healy, Phys. Rev. Lett. 62, 442 (1989)], and treated by functional

RG methods [L. Balents and D.S. Fisher, Phys. Rev. B 48, 5949 (1993)]. The same model has also been studied by a variational approach that involves replica symmetry breaking [M. Mèzard and G. Parisi, J. Physique I 1, 809 (1991); J. Phys. A 23, L1229 (1990); J. Physique I 2, 2231 (1992)]. The latter is also exact in the D→∞D \rightarrow \inftyD→∞ limit. Directed paths have been examined on non-Euclidean lattices: In particular, the problem can be solved exactly on the Cayley tree [B. Derrida and H. Spohn, J. Stat. Phys. 51, 817 (1988)] where it has a transition between a "free" and a glassy state. There are also quite a few treatments based on a position space renormalization group scheme [B. Derrida and R.B. Griffiths, Europhys. Lett. 8, 111 (1989); J. Cook and B. Derrida, J. Stat. Phys. 57, 89 (1989)] which becomes exact on a hierarchical lattice [see A.N. Berker and S. Ostlund, J. Phys. C 12, 4961 (1979); and references therein]. This lattice has no loops, and at the (m+1)(m+1)(m+1) th level is constructed by putting together 2D2^{D}2D branches, each containing two lattices of the mmm th level. Starting from a set of random bonds at the first level, the values of the sum W(m=log⁡2t)W\left(m=\log _{2} t\right)W(m=log2​t) are constructed recursively from

W(m+1,β)=∑α=12DW(m,α1)W(m,α2),\begin{equation*} W(m+1, \beta)=\sum_{\alpha=1}^{2^{D}} W\left(m, \alpha_{1}\right) W\left(m, \alpha_{2}\right), \tag{10.88} \end{equation*}W(m+1,β)=α=1∑2D​W(m,α1​)W(m,α2​),​(10.88)​

where the Greek indices are used to indicate specific bonds for a particular realization. Alternatively, these recursion relations can be used to study the evolution of the probability distribution for WWW [S. Roux, A. Hansen, L.R. di Silva, L.S. Lucena, and R.B. Pandey, J. Stat. Phys. 65, 183 (1991)]. The exponent ω≈0.30\omega \approx 0.30ω≈0.30 for D=1D=1D=1 is not too far off from the exact value of 1/31 / 31/3.

Additional information about the higher dimensional DPRM is obtained by taking advantage of a mapping to the non-equilibrium problem of kinetic roughening of growing interfaces. Using the Cole-Hopf transformation [E. Hopf, Comm. Pure Appl. Math. 3, 201 (1950); J.D. Cole, Quart. Appl. Math. 9, 225 (1951)],

W(x⃗,t)=exp⁡[−λh(x⃗,t)2ν],\begin{equation*} W(\vec{x}, t)=\exp \left[-\frac{\lambda h(\vec{x}, t)}{2 \nu}\right], \tag{10.89} \end{equation*}W(x,t)=exp[−2νλh(x,t)​],​(10.89)​

Fig. 10.5 The hierarchical lattice corresponding to Eq. (10.88).

Eq. (10.83) is transformed to the Kardar, Parisi, Zhang (KPZ) [M. Kardar, G. Parisi, and Y.-C. Zhang, Phys. Rev. Lett. 56, 889 (1986)] equation,

∂h∂t=2νλξ+ν∇2h−λ2(∇h)2−2νλμ(x⃗,t),\begin{equation*} \frac{\partial h}{\partial t}=\frac{2 \nu}{\lambda \xi}+\nu \nabla^{2} h-\frac{\lambda}{2}(\nabla h)^{2}-\frac{2 \nu}{\lambda} \mu(\vec{x}, t), \tag{10.90} \end{equation*}∂t∂h​=λξ2ν​+ν∇2h−2λ​(∇h)2−λ2ν​μ(x,t),​(10.90)​

describing the fluctuations in height h(x⃗,t)h(\vec{x}, t)h(x,t) of a growing interface (see the discussion in Sec 9.6). A dynamical renormalization group (RG) analysis at the one-loop level [D. Forster, D.R. Nelson, and M.J. Stephen, Phys. Rev. A 16, 732 (1977)] [E. Medina, T. Hwa, M. Kardar, and Y.-C. Zhang, Phys. Rev. A 39, 3053 (1989)] of this equation indicates that the effective coupling constant g=4σ2/νg=4 \sigma^{2} / \nug=4σ2/ν, satisfies the rescaling relation

dg dℓ=(2−D)g+C(D)g2\begin{equation*} \frac{\mathrm{dg}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=(2-D) g+C(D) g^{2} \tag{10.91} \end{equation*} dℓdg​=(2−D)g+C(D)g2​(10.91)​

where C(D)=KD(2D−3)/DC(D)=K_{D}(2 D-3) / DC(D)=KD​(2D−3)/D and KDK_{D}KD​ is the DDD-dimensional solid angle divided by (2π)D(2 \pi)^{D}(2π)D. The RG equation merely confirms the expectations based on the replica analysis: there is flow to strong coupling for D≤2D \leq 2D≤2 (formation of a bound state), while there is a transition between weak (unbound) and strong (bound) coupling behavior in higher dimensions. Can a perturbation analysis at higher order provide information about the scaling behavior in the strong coupling regime [T. Sun and M. Plischke, Phys. Rev. E 49, 5046 (1994)]; [E. Frey and U.C. Täuber, Phys. Rev. E 50, 1024 (1994)]? The above analogy to attracting particles in quantum mechanics negates this possibility. In fact Wiese [K.J. Wiese, J. Stat. Phys. 93, 143 (1998)] has shown that to all orders in perturbation theory, the above form remains unchanged, with an exact value of

C(D)=2Γ(2−d/2)(8π)d/2C(D)=\frac{2 \Gamma(2-d / 2)}{(8 \pi)^{d / 2}}C(D)=(8π)d/22Γ(2−d/2)​

Since there are several comprehensive reviews of the KPZ equation [see, e.g. Dynamics of Fractal Surfaces, edited by F. Family and T. Vicsek (World Scientific, Singapore, 1991); J. Krug and H. Spohn, in Solids Far From Equilibrium: Growth, Morphology and Defects, edited by C. Godreche (Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1991)]. I will not discuss its properties in any detail here. It suffices to say that there are many numerical models of growth that fall in the universality class of this equation. They are in complete agreement with the exactly known results for D=1D=1D=1. The estimates for the exponent ζ\zetaζ in higher dimensions are ζ=0.624±0.001\zeta=0.624 \pm 0.001ζ=0.624±0.001 for D=2D=2D=2 [B.M. Forrest and L.-H. Tang, Phys. Rev. Lett. 64, 1405 (1990)] and ζ≈0.59\zeta \approx 0.59ζ≈0.59 for D=3D=3D=3 [J.M. Kim, A.J. Bray, and M.A. Moore, Phys. Rev. A 44, 2345 (1991)]. The numerical results in higher dimensions are consistent with an exponent ζ\zetaζ that gets closer to 1/21 / 21/2 as D→∞D \rightarrow \inftyD→∞. It is not presently known whether there is a finite upper critical dimension [T. Halpin-Healy, Phys. Rev. Lett. 62, 442 (1989); M.A. Moore, T. Blum, J.P. Doherty, M. Marsili, J.-P. Bouchaud, and P. Claudin, Phys. Rev. Lett. 74, 4257 (1995)] beyond which ζ=1/2\zeta=1 / 2ζ=1/2 exactly.

10.8 Random signs
