We can gain some analytic understanding of the distribution function for I(t,B)I(t, B)I(t,B) by examining the moments I(t)n‾\overline{I(t)^{n}}I(t)n​. From Eqs. (10.115) and (10.116) we see that each I(t)I(t)I(t) represents a forward path from iii to fff, and a time reversed path from fff to iii. For I(t)n‾\overline{I(t)^{n}}I(t)n​, we have to average over the contributions of nnn such pairs of paths. Averaging over the random signs of the site energies forces a pairing of the 2n2 n2n paths (since any site crossed by an odd number of paths leads to a zero contribution). To understand the MC, it is useful to distinguish two classes of pairings: (1) Neutral paths in which one member is selected from JJJ and the other from J†J^{\dagger}J†. Such pairs do not feel the field since the phase factors of eiA\mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{iA}}eiA picked up by one member on each bond are canceled by the conjugate factors e−iA\mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{iA}}e−iA collected by its partner. (2) Charged paths in which both elements are taken from JJJ or from J†J^{\dagger}J†. Such pairs couple to the magnetic field like particles of charge ±2e\pm 2 e±2e.

In the presence of SO, we must also average over the random SU(2)S U(2)SU(2) matrices. From the orthogonality relation for group representations [H.F. Jones, Groups, Representations and Physics (Adam Hilger, Bristol and New York, 1990)], we have

∫Γk(g)ij∗Γk′(g)i′j′W(α1,⋯ ,αn)dα1⋯ dαn=δii′δjj′δkk′λk∫W(α1,⋯ ,αn)dα1⋯ dαn\begin{align*} & \int \Gamma^{k}(g)_{i j}^{*} \Gamma^{k^{\prime}}(g)_{i^{\prime} j^{\prime}} W\left(\alpha_{1}, \cdots, \alpha_{n}\right) \mathrm{d} \alpha_{1} \cdots \mathrm{~d} \alpha_{n} \\ & =\frac{\delta_{i i^{\prime}} \delta_{j j^{\prime}} \delta_{k k^{\prime}}}{\lambda_{k}} \int W\left(\alpha_{1}, \cdots, \alpha_{n}\right) \mathrm{d} \alpha_{1} \cdots \mathrm{~d} \alpha_{n} \tag{10.120} \end{align*}​∫Γk(g)ij∗​Γk′(g)i′j′​W(α1​,⋯,αn​)dα1​⋯ dαn​=λk​δii′​δjj′​δkk′​​∫W(α1​,⋯,αn​)dα1​⋯ dαn​​(10.120)​

where Γk(g)ij\Gamma^{k}(g)_{i j}Γk(g)ij​ is the iji jij matrix element of a representation of the group element g,W(α1,⋯ ,αn)g, W\left(\alpha_{1}, \cdots, \alpha_{n}\right)g,W(α1​,⋯,αn​) is an appropriate weight function so that the matrix space is sampled uniformly as the continuous parameters α1,⋯ ,αn\alpha_{1}, \cdots, \alpha_{n}α1​,⋯,αn​ vary (e.g. Euler angles for a representation of SU(2)S U(2)SU(2) ). Finally λk\lambda_{k}λk​ is the order of the representation kkk. Choosing the Euler angle parameterization of SU(2)S U(2)SU(2) it can be shown that the only non-zero paired averages are

uαβuαβ∗‾=12,u↑↑u↓↓‾=12,u↑↓u↓↑‾=−12,\begin{equation*} \overline{u_{\alpha \beta} u_{\alpha \beta}^{*}}=\frac{1}{2}, \quad \overline{u_{\uparrow \uparrow} u_{\downarrow \downarrow}}=\frac{1}{2}, \quad \overline{u_{\uparrow \downarrow} u_{\downarrow \uparrow}}=-\frac{1}{2}, \tag{10.121} \end{equation*}uαβ​uαβ∗​​=21​,u↑↑​u↓↓​​=21​,u↑↓​u↓↑​​=−21​,​(10.121)​

and their complex conjugates. Thus SO averaging forces neutral paths to carry parallel spins, while the spins on the two partners of charged paths must be anti-parallel.

We next consider the statistical weights associated with the intersections of paths. These weights depend crucially on the symmetries of the Hamiltonian in Eq. (10.114): For B=0B=0B=0 and without SO, the Hamiltonian has orthogonal symmetry. All pairings are allowed and the attraction factor is 3 , since an incoming (12) (34) can go to (12) (34), (13) (24), or (14) (23). Note that even if both incoming paths are neutral, one of the exchanged configurations is charged. A magnetic field breaks time reversal symmetry, discourages charged configurations, and reduces the exchange attraction. The limiting case of a

Fig. 10.12 Averaging over randomness joins paths in pairs: Neutral paths arise from pairing of complex conjugate paths and have parallel spins. Pairing paths that are not complex conjugates (arrows in the same direction) lead to charged paths which feel the magnetic field, and carry opposite spins. "large" magnetic field is mimicked by replacing the gauge factors with random phases. In this extreme, the Hamiltonian has unitary symmetry and only neutral paths are allowed. The exchange factor is now reduced to 2 ; from (11∗)(22∗)→\left(11^{*}\right)\left(22^{*}\right) \rightarrow(11∗)(22∗)→ (11∗)(22∗)\left(11^{*}\right)\left(22^{*}\right)(11∗)(22∗), or (12∗)(21∗)\left(12^{*}\right)\left(21^{*}\right)(12∗)(21∗). With SO averaging, we must also take into account the allowed spin exchanges: Two neutral paths entering the intersection can have indices (αα),(αα)(\alpha \alpha),(\alpha \alpha)(αα),(αα) or (αα),(αα‾)(\alpha \alpha),(\overline{\alpha \alpha})(αα),(αα); there are 2 possibilities for the first ( α=↑\alpha=\uparrowα=↑ or ↓\downarrow↓ ) and two for the second ( αˉ\bar{\alpha}αˉ is antiparallel to α\alphaα ). In the former case, however, there are two exchanges preserving neutrality, while in the latter only one exchange is possible satisfying this constraint. Hence an overall multiplicity of [2×2+2×1]×(1/2)2=3/2[2 \times 2+2 \times 1] \times(1 / 2)^{2}=3 / 2[2×2+2×1]×(1/2)2=3/2 is obtained, where the (1/2)2(1 / 2)^{2}(1/2)2 comes from the averages in Eq. (10.121). Thus the intersection of two paired paths results in an exchange attraction of 3/23 / 23/2; a signature of the symplectic symmetry.

Based on the above symmetry dependent statistical attraction factors, we can provide an understanding of the numerical results for MC. The sum over nnn attracting paths again leads to

⟨I(t)n⟩=A(n)2ntexp⁡[ρn(n2−1)t]\begin{equation*} \left\langle I(t)^{n}\right\rangle=A(n) 2^{n t} \exp \left[\rho n\left(n^{2}-1\right) t\right] \tag{10.122} \end{equation*}⟨I(t)n⟩=A(n)2ntexp[ρn(n2−1)t]​(10.122)​

where we have also allowed for an overall nnn-dependent amplitude. Without SO, the magnetic field gradually reduces the attraction factor from 3 to 2 leading to the increase in slope. Addition of SO to the Hamiltonian has the effect of suddenly decreasing the attraction factor to 3/23 / 23/2. Why does the addition of the magnetic field lead to no further change in ρ\rhoρ in the presence of SO? Without SO, the origin of the continuous change in the attraction factor is a charged bubble that may appear in between successive intersections of two neutral paths. In the presence of SO, from the averages in Eq. (10.121) we find the contribution of such configurations to be zero. To produce intermediate charged paths (with their antiparallel spins), the entering pair must have indices of the type (i iii ), ( iˉiˉ)\bar{i} \bar{i})iˉiˉ) (where ↓ˉ=↑\bar{\downarrow}=\uparrow↓ˉ​=↑, and ↑ˉ=↓\bar{\uparrow}=\downarrow↑ˉ​=↓ ). Within the bubble we can have intermediate sites labeled (jjˉ)(j \bar{j})(jjˉ​) and (kkˉ)(k \bar{k})(kkˉ) which must be summed over due to matrix contractions. It is easy to check that, independent of the choice of jjj, if the incoming and outgoing spins (i(i(i and m)m)m) are the same on a branch it contributes a positive sign, while if they are opposite the overall sign is negative. However, for any choice of iii and mmm, one may choose similar (e.g. i→mi \rightarrow mi→m on both branches), or opposite (e.g. i→mi \rightarrow mi→m on top and i→mˉi \rightarrow \bar{m}i→mˉ on lower branch) connections. The difference in sign between the two choices thus cancels their overall contributions. Hence the neutral paths traverse the system without being affected by charged segments. In a magnetic field, their attraction factor stays at 3/23 / 23/2 and ρ=ξg−1\rho=\xi_{g}^{-1}ρ=ξg−1​ is unchanged.

The smaller positive MC observed in the simulations is due to changes in the amplitude A(n)A(n)A(n) in Eq. (10.122). This originates from the charged paths that contribute to tunneling at small BBB but are quenched at higher BBB. However, due to their lack of interactions, we may treat the charged and neutral paths as independent. At zero field any of the pairings into charged and neutral paths is acceptable, while at finite fields only neutral pairs survive. This leads to a reduction in the amplitude A(n)A(n)A(n) for n≥2n \geq 2n≥2, but an increase in ln⁡I\ln IlnI (a positive MC ). The typical value of ln⁡I\ln IlnI thus increases by a ttt independent amount. This behavior is similar to the predictions of IPA, and is indeed due to the independence of charged and neutral paths. Since the typical scale of decay for charged paths depends on the combination Bt3/2B t^{3 / 2}Bt3/2 (typical flux through a random walk of length ttt, we can explain the scaling obtained numerically in Eq. (10.119).

The exchange attraction between neutral paths can also be computed for (unphysical) SU(n)S U(n)SU(n) impurities and equals 1+1/n1+1 / n1+1/n, which reproduces 2 for U(1)U(1)U(1) or random phases, and 3/23 / 23/2 for SU(2)S U(2)SU(2) or SO scattering. The attraction vanishes in the n→∞n \rightarrow \inftyn→∞ limit, where the paths become independent. The statistical exchange factors are thus universal numbers, simply related to the symmetries of the underlying Hamiltonian. The attractions in turn are responsible for the formation of bound states in replica space, and the universal scaling of the moments in Eq. (10.122). In fact, since the single parameter ρ\rhoρ completely

Fig. 10.13 Magneto-conductance can be traced to the influence of loops of charged paths. characterizes the distribution, the variations in the mean and variance of ln⁡I(t)\ln I(t)lnI(t) should be perfectly correlated. This can be tested numerically by examining respectively coefficients of the mean and the variance for different cases. All results do indeed fall on a single line, parameterized by ρ\rhoρ. The largest value corresponds to the NSS model for B=0B=0B=0 and no SO (orthogonal symmetry, exchange attraction 3). Introduction of a field gradually reduces ρ\rhoρ until saturated at the limit of random phases (unitary symmetry, exchange attraction 2). SO scattering reduces ρ\rhoρ further (symplectic symmetry, exchange attraction 3/2).

10.13 Unitary propagation

We can put together the results discussed so far by generalizing Eq. (10.83) to allow for complex (and matrix valued) parameters. In the originally encountered directed polymer, the parameters ν>0\nu>0ν>0 and μ\muμ appearing in this equation were both real. To discuss the wavefunction in a magnetic field, we have to allow μ\muμ to take complex values. Finally, SO scattering is included by generalizing WWW to a two component spinor, and using matrix valued μ\muμ. We found that in all these cases the statistical behavior of ln⁡W(x,t)\ln W(\mathbf{x}, t)lnW(x,t) is the same. Is this a general property of Eq. (10.83), independent of the choice of parameters? A special limit of this equation is when both μ→−iμ\mu \rightarrow-\mathrm{i} \muμ→−iμ and ν→−iν\nu \rightarrow-\mathrm{i} \nuν→−iν are purely imaginary. Then Eq. (10.83) reduces to the Schrödinger equation

i∂W∂t=[ν∇2+μ(x⃗,t)]W\begin{equation*} \mathrm{i} \frac{\partial W}{\partial t}=\left[\nu \nabla^{2}+\mu(\vec{x}, t)\right] W \tag{10.123} \end{equation*}i∂t∂W​=[ν∇2+μ(x,t)]W​(10.123)​

for a particle in a random time-dependent potential. This equation has been considered in the context of particle diffusion in crystals at finite temperature [J.-P. Bouchaud, Europhys. Lett. 11, 505 (1990)]; [A.A. Ovchinnikov and N.S. Erikhman, Sov. Phys. JETP 40, 733 (1975)]; [A.M. Jayannavar and N. Kumar, Phys. Rev. Lett. 48, 553 (1982)], and to model the environment of a light test particle in a gas of much heavier particles [L. Golubovic, S. Feng, and F. Zeng, Phys. Rev. Lett. 67, 2115 (1991)]. Several authors [R. Dashen, J. Math Phys. 20, 894 (1979)]; [H. de Raedt, A. Lagendijk, and P. de Vries, Phys. Rev. Lett. 62, 47 (1988)]; [S. Feng, L. Golubovic, and Y.-C. Zhang, Phys. Rev. Lett. 65, 1028 (1990)] have also suggested that the diffusion of directed wave fronts in disordered media are described by Eq. (10.123).

The path-integral solution to Eq. (10.123) is

W(x,t)=∫(0,0)(x⃗,t)Dx⃗(t′)exp⁡{−i∫0t dt′[14ν( dx⃗ dt′)2+μ(x⃗(t′,t′)]},\begin{equation*} W(x, t)=\int_{(0,0)}^{(\vec{x}, t)} \mathcal{D} \vec{x}\left(t^{\prime}\right) \exp \left\{-\mathrm{i} \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} t^{\prime}\left[\frac{1}{4 \nu}\left(\frac{\mathrm{~d} \vec{x}}{\mathrm{~d} t^{\prime}}\right)^{2}+\mu\left(\vec{x}\left(t^{\prime}, t^{\prime}\right)\right]\right\},\right. \tag{10.124} \end{equation*}W(x,t)=∫(0,0)(x,t)​Dx(t′)exp{−i∫0t​ dt′[4ν1​( dt′ dx​)2+μ(x(t′,t′)]},​(10.124)​

where x(t′)x\left(t^{\prime}\right)x(t′) now describes a path in d−1d-1d−1 dimensions. In writing Eq. (10.124), we have chosen the standard initial condition that at time t=0t=0t=0 the "wavefunction" is localized at the origin. The beam positions ⟨x2⟩‾\overline{\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle}⟨x2⟩​ and ⟨x⟩2‾\overline{\langle x\rangle^{2}}⟨x⟩2​ characterize the transverse fluctuations of a directed beam W(x⃗,t)W(\vec{x}, t)W(x,t) about the forward path of least scattering. Here we use ⟨⋯ ⟩\langle\cdots\rangle⟨⋯⟩ to indicate an average with the weight ∣W(x,t)∣2|W(x, t)|^{2}∣W(x,t)∣2 for a given realization, and ⋯\cdots⋯ to indicate quenched averaging over all realizations of randomness. Roughly speaking, ⟨x⟩2‾\overline{\langle x\rangle^{2}}⟨x⟩2​ describes the wandering of the beam center, while ⟨x2⟩‾−⟨x⟩2\overline{\left\langle x^{2}\right\rangle}-\langle x\rangle^{2}⟨x2⟩​−⟨x⟩2 provides a measure of the beam width.

A special property of Eq. (10.123) which is valid only for real ν\nuν and μ\muμ is unitarity, i.e. the norm ∫dx⃗∣W(x⃗,t)∣2\int \mathrm{d} \vec{x}|W(\vec{x}, t)|^{2}∫dx∣W(x,t)∣2 is preserved at all times. (In the directed polymer and tunneling problems, the norm clearly decays with the length ttt.) This additional conservation law sets apart the random directed wave problem from directed polymers, and in a sense makes its solution more tractable. Unitarity is of course a natural consequence of particle conservation for the Schrödinger equation, but has no counterpart for directed wave propagation. It is likely that a beam of light propagating in a random medium will suffer a loss of intensity, due to either back-reflection, inelastic scattering, or localization phenomena [for a review of localization of light, see S. John, Physics Today, 32 (May 1991)].

A number of efforts at understanding unitary propagation in random media have focused on the scaling behavior of the beam positions ⟨x⟩‾2\overline{\langle x\rangle}^{2}⟨x⟩​2 and ⟨x⟩‾2\overline{\langle x\rangle}^{2}⟨x⟩​2 at large ttt. Lattice models have been used here with some success. It has been shown using density-matrix techniques, for instance, that ⟨x⟩‾2\overline{\langle x\rangle}^{2}⟨x⟩​2 scales linearly in time as a consequence of unitarity [A.A. Ovchinnikov and N.S. Erikhman, Sov. Phys. JETP 40, 733 (1975)]; numerical simulations [E. Medina, M. Kardar, and H. Spohn, Phys. Rev. Lett. 66, 2176 (1991)]; [J.-P. Bouchaud, D. Touati, and D. Sornette, Phys. Rev. Lett. 68, 1787 (1992)] also support this view. The scaling behavior of ⟨x⟩‾2\overline{\langle x\rangle}^{2}⟨x⟩​2 at large ttt, however, is somewhat more complicated. An early numerical simulation in [S. Feng, L. Golubovic, and Y.-C. Zhang, Phys. Rev. Lett. 65, 1028 (1990)] employed a discretization procedure in which the norm of the wave function was not strictly preserved. In 2d2 d2d, this leads to ⟨x⟩‾2\overline{\langle x\rangle}^{2}⟨x⟩​2 growing super-diffusively as tζt^{\zeta}tζ with ζ≈3/4\zeta \approx 3 / 4ζ≈3/4, and in 3d3 d3d a phase transition separating regimes of weak and strong disorder. However, subsequent numerical studies [E. Medina, M. Kardar, and H. Spohn, Phys. Rev. Lett. 66, 2176 (1991)] on directed waves, when the time evolution is strictly unitary, indicate that ⟨x⟩‾2\overline{\langle x\rangle}^{2}⟨x⟩​2 scales subdiffusively in 2d2 d2d with ζ≈0.3\zeta \approx 0.3ζ≈0.3.

Somewhat surprising is the fact that a continuum formulation of the wave problem leads to different results. An exact treatment of the continuum Schrödinger equation (10.102) has been given by Jayannavar and Kumar [A.M. Jayannavar and N. Kumar, Phys. Rev. Lett. 48, 553 (1982)]. They show that for a random potential δ\deltaδ-correlated in time, ⟨x⟩‾2∼t3\overline{\langle x\rangle}^{2} \sim t^{3}⟨x⟩​2∼t3 as t→∞t \rightarrow \inftyt→∞. This behavior is modified when there are short-range correlations in time [L. Golubovic, S. Feng, and F. Zeng, Phys. Rev. Lett. 67, 2115 (1991)] but the motion remains non-diffusive in that the particle is accelerated indefinitely as t→∞t \rightarrow \inftyt→∞. Lattice models introduce a momentum cutoff pmax⁡∼a−1p_{\max } \sim a^{-1}pmax​∼a−1, where aaa is the lattice spacing, and therefore do not exhibit this effect. The momentum cutoff generated by the lattice discretization is in some sense artificial. Nevertheless, in a real fluctuating medium, we do expect on large time scales to recover the lattice result, i.e. normal diffusion. The reason is that dissipative effects do generate an effective momentum cutoff in most physical systems. (Strictly speaking, even in the absence of dissipation, relativistic constraints lead to a velocity cutoff v=cv=cv=c.) The presence of such a cutoff for the wave propagation problem, and hence the physical relevance of lattice versus continuum models, is still a matter of debate. While there is no underlying lattice, one suspects on physical grounds that there does exist an effective momentum cutoff for propagating waves, related to the speed of light in the background medium.

Standard numerical investigations of this problem start with a discretization of the parabolic wave equation in Eq. (10.123). Alternatively, one can treat the path integral representation as more fundamental and provide a direct discretization of Eq. (10.124) that preserves unitarity [L. Saul, M. Kardar, and N. Read, Phys. Rev. A 45, 8859 (1992)]. For concreteness, we introduce the model in 2d2 d2d. A discussion of its generalization to higher dimensions is taken up later. As usual, we identify the time axis with the primary direction of propagation and orient it along the diagonal of the square lattice. The wave function is defined on the bonds of this lattice. We use W±(x,t)W_{ \pm}(x, t)W±​(x,t) to refer to the amplitude for arriving at the site (x,t)(x, t)(x,t) from the ±x\pm x±x direction. At t=0t=0t=0, the wave function is localized at the origin, with W±(0,0)=1/2W_{ \pm}(0,0)=1 / \sqrt{2}W±​(0,0)=1/2​. Transfer matrix techniques are then used to simulate diffusion in the presence of disorder. At time ttt, we imagine that a random scattering event occurs at each site on the lattice at which either W+(x,t)W_{+}(x, t)W+​(x,t) or W−(x,t)W_{-}(x, t)W−​(x,t) is non-zero. We implement these events by assigning to each scattering site a 2×22 \times 22×2 unitary matrix S(x,t)S(x, t)S(x,t). The values of the wave function at time t+1t+1t+1 are then computed from the recursion relation:

(W−(x+1,t+1)W+(x−1,t+1))=(S11(x,t)S12(x,t)S21(x,t)S22(x,t))(W−(x,t)W+(x,t)).(10.125)\binom{W_{-}(x+1, t+1)}{W_{+}(x-1, t+1)}=\left(\begin{array}{ll} S_{11}(x, t) & S_{12}(x, t) \tag{10.125}\\ S_{21}(x, t) & S_{22}(x, t) \end{array}\right)\binom{W_{-}(x, t)}{W_{+}(x, t)} .(W+​(x−1,t+1)W−​(x+1,t+1)​)=(S11​(x,t)S21​(x,t)​S12​(x,t)S22​(x,t)​)(W+​(x,t)W−​(x,t)​).(10.125)

The SSS-matrices are required to be unitary in order to locally preserve the norm of the wave function. As a particular instance, we may consider the rotation matrix

S(θ,ϕ)=(cos⁡(θ/2)eiϕsin⁡(θ/2)e−iϕ−sin⁡(θ/2)eiϕcos⁡(θ/2)e−iϕ).(10.126)S(\theta, \phi)=\left(\begin{array}{cc} \cos (\theta / 2) \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \phi} & \sin (\theta / 2) \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} \phi} \tag{10.126}\\ -\sin (\theta / 2) \mathrm{e}^{\mathrm{i} \phi} & \cos (\theta / 2) \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} \phi} \end{array}\right) .S(θ,ϕ)=(cos(θ/2)eiϕ−sin(θ/2)eiϕ​sin(θ/2)e−iϕcos(θ/2)e−iϕ​).(10.126)

A physical realization of this model is obtained by placing semi-polished mirrors of variable thickness, parallel to the ttt axis, on the sites of a square lattice. Within this framework, it should be clear that the value of W±(x,t)W_{ \pm}(x, t)W±​(x,t) is obtained by summing the individual amplitudes of all directed paths which start at the origin and arrive at the point (x,t)(x, t)(x,t) from the ±x\pm x±x direction. We thus have a unitary discretization of the path integral in Eq. (10.124) in which the phase change from the potential μ(x,t)\mu(x, t)μ(x,t) is replaced by an element of the matrix S(x,t)S(x, t)S(x,t). A lattice SSS-matrix approach for the study of electron localization and the quantum Hall effect has been used by Chalker and Coddington [J.T. Chalker and P.D. Coddington, J. Phys. C21, 2665 (1988)]. A related model has also been used [C. Vanneste, P. Sebbah, and D. Sornette, Europhys. Lett. 17, 715 (1992)] to investigate the localization of wave packets in random media. These models also include back scattering and hence involve a larger matrix at each site.

10.14 Unitary averages

A particularly nice feature of unitary propagation is that the weights W(x,t)W(x, t)W(x,t) are automatically normalized. In particular, we are interested in the beam positions

⟨x2(t)⟩‾=∑xP(x,t)‾x2\begin{equation*} \overline{\left\langle x^{2}(t)\right\rangle}=\sum_{x} \overline{P(x, t)} x^{2} \tag{10.127} \end{equation*}⟨x2(t)⟩​=x∑​P(x,t)​x2​(10.127)​

and

⟨x(t)⟩2‾=∑x1,x2P(x1,t)P(x2,t)‾x1x2,\begin{equation*} \overline{\langle x(t)\rangle^{2}}=\sum_{x_{1}, x_{2}} \overline{P\left(x_{1}, t\right) P\left(x_{2}, t\right)} x_{1} x_{2}, \tag{10.128} \end{equation*}⟨x(t)⟩2​=x1​,x2​∑​P(x1​,t)P(x2​,t)​x1​x2​,​(10.128)​

where P(x,t)P(x, t)P(x,t) is the probability distribution function on the lattice at time ttt, defined by

P(x,t)=∣W+Plus(x,t)∣2+∣W−(x,t)∣2.\begin{equation*} P(x, t)=\left|W_{+} P l u s(x, t)\right|^{2}+\left|W_{-}(x, t)\right|^{2} . \tag{10.129} \end{equation*}P(x,t)=∣W+​Plus(x,t)∣2+∣W−​(x,t)∣2.​(10.129)​

(Defining the weights directly on the bonds does not substantially change the results.) Note that unlike the directed polymer problem, P(x,t)P(x, t)P(x,t) is properly normalized, i.e.

∑xP(x,t)=1\sum_{x} P(x, t)=1x∑​P(x,t)=1

and Eqs. (10.127) and (10.128) are not divided by normalizations such as ∑xP(x,t)\sum_{x} P(x, t)∑x​P(x,t). This simplification is a consequence of unitarity and makes the directed wave problem tractable.

The average ⋯\cdots⋯, in Eqs. (10.127) and (10.128) is to be performed over a distribution of SSS-matrices that closely resembles the corresponding distribution for μ\muμ in the continuum problem. However, by analogy to the directed polymer problem we expect any disorder to be relevant. Hence, to obtain the asymptotic scaling behavior, we consider the extreme limit of strong scattering in which each matrix S(x,t)S(x, t)S(x,t) is an independently chosen random element of the group U(2)U(2)U(2). With such a distribution we lose any pre-asymptotic behavior associated with weak scattering [L. Golubovic, S. Feng, and F. Zeng, Phys. Rev. Lett. 67, 2115 (1991)]. The results are expected to be valid over a range of length scales a≪x≪ξa \ll x \ll \xia≪x≪ξ, where aaa is a distance over which the change of phase due to randomness is around 2π2 \pi2π, and ξ\xiξ is the characteristic length for the decay of intensity and breakdown of unitarity. In the language of path integrals, the quantity P(x,t)‾\overline{P(x, t)}P(x,t)​ represents the average over a conjugate pair of paths (from W±W_{ \pm}W±​ and W±∗W_{ \pm}^{*}W±∗​ respectively.) As in the random sign problem, the paths must be exactly paired to make a non-zero contribution (since Sαβ‾=0\overline{S_{\alpha \beta}}=0Sαβ​​=0 ). In the strong disorder limit, each step along the paired paths contributes a factor of 1/21 / 21/2. (It can be easily checked from Eq. (10.126) that ∣Sαβ∣2‾=cos⁡2(θ/2)‾=sin⁡2(θ/2)‾=1/2\overline{\left|S_{\alpha \beta}\right|^{2}}=\overline{\cos ^{2}(\theta / 2)}=\overline{\sin ^{2}(\theta / 2)}=1 / 2∣Sαβ​∣2​=cos2(θ/2)​=sin2(θ/2)​=1/2.) Thus, in this limit, the effect of an impurity at (x,t)(x, t)(x,t) is to redistribute the incident probability flux P(x,t)P(x, t)P(x,t) at random in the +x+x+x and −x-x−x directions. On average, the flux is scattered symmetrically so that the disorder-averaged probability describes the event space of a classical random walk, i.e.

P(x,t)‾=t!(t−x2)!(t+x2)!\begin{equation*} \overline{P(x, t)}=\frac{t!}{\left(\frac{t-x}{2}\right)!\left(\frac{t+x}{2}\right)!} \tag{10.130} \end{equation*}P(x,t)​=(2t−x​)!(2t+x​)!t!​​(10.130)​

Substituting this into Eq. (10.127), we find ⟨x2(t)⟩‾=t\overline{\left\langle x^{2}(t)\right\rangle}=t⟨x2(t)⟩​=t, in agreement with previous studies [A.A. Ovchinnikov and N.S. Erikhman, Sov. Phys. JETP 40, 733 (1975)].

Consider now the position of the beam center ⟨x(t)⟩2‾\overline{\langle x(t)\rangle^{2}}⟨x(t)⟩2​, given by Eq. (10.128). Unlike P(x,t)‾\overline{P(x, t)}P(x,t)​, the correlation function P(x1,t)P(x2,t)‾\overline{P\left(x_{1}, t\right) P\left(x_{2}, t\right)}P(x1​,t)P(x2​,t)​ does not have a simple form. It involves a sum over four paths, collapsed into two pairs by randomness averaging. The center of mass coordinate R=(x1+x2)/2R=\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right) / 2R=(x1​+x2​)/2 performs a random walk with R2‾=t/2\overline{R^{2}}=t / 2R2=t/2. Let us define a new correlation function for the relative coordinate r=x2−x1r=x_{2}-x_{1}r=x2​−x1​ as

W2(r,t)=∑RP(R−r/2,t)P(R+r/2,t)‾,\begin{equation*} W_{2}(r, t)=\sum_{R} \overline{P(R-r / 2, t) P(R+r / 2, t)}, \tag{10.131} \end{equation*}W2​(r,t)=R∑​P(R−r/2,t)P(R+r/2,t)​,​(10.131)​

with the initial condition

W2(r,t=0)=δr,0.\begin{equation*} W_{2}(r, t=0)=\delta_{r, 0} . \tag{10.132} \end{equation*}W2​(r,t=0)=δr,0​.​(10.132)​

The value of W2(r,t)W_{2}(r, t)W2​(r,t) is the disorder-averaged probability that two paired paths, evolved in the same realization of randomness, are separated by a distance rrr at time ttt, and can be computed as a sum over all configurations that meet this criterion. Consider now the evolution of two such pairs from time ttt to t+1t+1t+1. Clearly, at times when r≠0r \neq 0r=0, the two pairs behave as independent random walks. On the other hand, when r=0r=0r=0, there is an increased probability that the paths move together as a result of participating in the same scattering event. An event in which the pairs stay together is enhanced (since ∣Sαβ∣4‾=cos⁡4(θ/2)‾=\overline{\left|S_{\alpha \beta}\right|^{4}}=\overline{\cos ^{4}(\theta / 2)}=∣Sαβ​∣4​=cos4(θ/2)​= sin⁡4(θ/2)‾=3/8\overline{\sin ^{4}(\theta / 2)}=3 / 8sin4(θ/2)​=3/8 ), while one in which the pairs separate is diminished (since sin⁡2(θ/2)cos⁡2(θ/2)‾=1/8\overline{\sin ^{2}(\theta / 2) \cos ^{2}(\theta / 2)}=1 / 8sin2(θ/2)cos2(θ/2)​=1/8 ). These observations lead to the following recursion relation for the evolution of W2(r,t)W_{2}(r, t)W2​(r,t),

W2(r,t+1)=(1+ϵδr,02)W2(r,t)+(1−ϵδr,24)W2(r−2,t)+(1−ϵδr,−24)W2(r+2,t).\begin{align*} W_{2}(r, t+1)= & \left(\frac{1+\epsilon \delta_{r, 0}}{2}\right) W_{2}(r, t)+\left(\frac{1-\epsilon \delta_{r, 2}}{4}\right) W_{2}(r-2, t) \tag{10.133}\\ & +\left(\frac{1-\epsilon \delta_{r,-2}}{4}\right) W_{2}(r+2, t) . \end{align*}W2​(r,t+1)=​(21+ϵδr,0​​)W2​(r,t)+(41−ϵδr,2​​)W2​(r−2,t)+(41−ϵδr,−2​​)W2​(r+2,t).​(10.133)​

The parameter ϵ≥0\epsilon \geq 0ϵ≥0 measures the tendency of the paths to stick together on contact. (If the SSS-matrix is uniformly distributed over the group U(2)U(2)U(2), then ϵ=1/4\epsilon=1 / 4ϵ=1/4.) Note that ∑rW2(r)\sum_{r} W_{2}(r)∑r​W2​(r) is preserved, as required by unitarity.

Using Eq. (10.133), we evolved W2(r,t)W_{2}(r, t)W2​(r,t) numerically for various values of 0<ϵ<10<\epsilon<10<ϵ<1 up to t≤15000t \leq 15000t≤15000. The position of the beam center was then calculated from

⟨x(t)⟩2‾=∑R,r(R2−r24)P(R−r/2,t)P(R+r/2,t)‾=t2−14∑rW2(r,t)r2.\begin{equation*} \overline{\langle x(t)\rangle^{2}}=\sum_{R, r}\left(R^{2}-\frac{r^{2}}{4}\right) \overline{P(R-r / 2, t) P(R+r / 2, t)}=\frac{t}{2}-\frac{1}{4} \sum_{r} W_{2}(r, t) r^{2} . \tag{10.134} \end{equation*}⟨x(t)⟩2​=R,r∑​(R2−4r2​)P(R−r/2,t)P(R+r/2,t)​=2t​−41​r∑​W2​(r,t)r2.​(10.134)​

The results suggest quite unambiguously that ⟨x(t)⟩‾2\overline{\langle x(t)\rangle}^{2}⟨x(t)⟩​2 scales as t2ζt^{2 \zeta}t2ζ, with ζ=\zeta=ζ= 1/41 / 41/4. We emphasize here the utility of the SSS-matrix model for directed waves in random media. Not only does our final algorithm compute averages over disorder in an exact way, but it requires substantially less time to do so than simulations which perform averages by statistical sampling as in DPRM. We have in fact confirmed our 2d2 d2d results with these slower methods on smaller lattices (t<2000)(t<2000)(t<2000).

The model is easily extended to higher dimensions. The wave function takes its values on the bonds of a lattice in ddd dimensions. Random d×dd \times dd×d dimensional SSS-matrices are then used to simulate scattering events at the sites of the lattice. When the matrices S(x⃗,t)S(\vec{x}, t)S(x,t) are distributed uniformly over the group U(d)U(d)U(d), the same considerations as before permit one to perform averages over disorder in an exact way. In addition, one obtains the general result for d≥2d \geq 2d≥2 that ⟨x⟩2‾\overline{\langle x\rangle^{2}}⟨x⟩2​ scales linearly in time. The computation of ⟨x⟩2‾\overline{\langle x\rangle^{2}}⟨x⟩2​ in d>2d>2d>2, of course, requires significantly more computer resources. We have computed ⟨x⟩2‾\overline{\langle x\rangle^{2}}⟨x⟩2​ on a d=3d=3d=3 body-centered cubic lattice, starting from the appropriate generalization of Eq. (10.133). The results for t<3000t<3000t<3000, indicate that ⟨x⟩2‾\overline{\langle x\rangle^{2}}⟨x⟩2​ scales logarithmically in time.

The above numerical results can be understood by appealing to some wellknown properties of random walks. Consider a random walker on a D=d−1D=d-1D=d−1 dimensional hypercubic lattice. We suppose, as usual, that the walker starts out at the origin, and that at times t=0,1,2,⋯t=0,1,2, \cdotst=0,1,2,⋯, the walker has probability 0<p≤1/2D0<p \leq 1 / 2 D0<p≤1/2D to move one step in any lattice direction and probability 1−2Dp1-2 D p1−2Dp to pause for a rest. The mean time t0t_{0}t0​ spent by the walker at the origin grows as [J.-P. Bouchaud and A. Georges, Phys. Rep. 195, 128 (1990)]

t0∼{t12(D=1)ln⁡t(D=2) constant (D=3)(10.135)t_{0} \sim \begin{cases}t^{\frac{1}{2}} & (D=1) \tag{10.135}\\ \ln t & (D=2) \\ \text { constant } & (D=3)\end{cases}t0​∼⎩⎨⎧​t21​lnt constant ​(D=1)(D=2)(D=3)​(10.135)

The numerical results indicate a similar scaling for the wandering of the beam center ⟨x⟩2‾\overline{\langle x\rangle^{2}}⟨x⟩2​ in d=D+1d=D+1d=D+1 dimensions, for d=2d=2d=2 and d=3d=3d=3. We now show that this equivalence is not coincidental; moreover, it strongly suggests that du=3d_{u}=3du​=3 is a critical dimension for directed waves in random media. To this end, let us consider a continuum version of Eq. (10.133), which in general dimensions takes the form

W2(r,t+1)=W2(r,t)+∇2[W2(1−ϵδD(r)+⋯ )].\begin{equation*} W_{2}(\mathbf{r}, t+1)=W_{2}(\mathbf{r}, t)+\nabla^{2}\left[W_{2}\left(1-\epsilon \delta^{D}(\mathbf{r})+\cdots\right)\right] . \tag{10.136} \end{equation*}W2​(r,t+1)=W2​(r,t)+∇2[W2​(1−ϵδD(r)+⋯)].​(10.136)​

The asymptotic solution for ϵ=0\epsilon=0ϵ=0 is just a Gaussian packet of width r2‾=2t\overline{r^{2}}=2 tr2=2t. We can next perform a perturbative calculation in ϵ\epsilonϵ. However, simple dimensional analysis shows the corrections scale as powers of ϵ/rD∼ϵt−D/2\epsilon / r^{D} \sim \epsilon t^{-D / 2}ϵ/rD∼ϵt−D/2, and thus

lim⁡t→∞W2(r,t)=1(4πt)D/2exp⁡(−r24t)[1+O(ϵt−(d−1)/2)]\begin{equation*} \lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} W_{2}(\mathbf{r}, t)=\frac{1}{(4 \pi t)^{D / 2}} \exp \left(-\frac{r^{2}}{4 t}\right)\left[1+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon t^{-(d-1) / 2}\right)\right] \tag{10.137} \end{equation*}t→∞lim​W2​(r,t)=(4πt)D/21​exp(−4tr2​)[1+O(ϵt−(d−1)/2)]​(10.137)​

Applying the above results to the continuum version of Eq. (10.133) gives

⟨x⟩t+12‾−⟨x⟩t2‾=12−14∑r[W2(r,t+1)−W2(r,t)]r2≃12−14∫ dDrr2∇2[W2(1−ϵδD(r)+⋯ )]≃12−12∫ dDrW2(1−ϵδD(r))=ϵW2(0,t)\begin{align*} \overline{\langle x\rangle_{t+1}^{2}}-\overline{\langle x\rangle_{t}^{2}} & =\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{4} \sum_{r}\left[W_{2}(r, t+1)-W_{2}(r, t)\right] r^{2} \\ & \simeq \frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{4} \int \mathrm{~d}^{D} \mathbf{r} r^{2} \nabla^{2}\left[W_{2}\left(1-\epsilon \delta^{D}(\mathbf{r})+\cdots\right)\right] \tag{10.138}\\ & \simeq \frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2} \int \mathrm{~d}^{D} \mathbf{r} W_{2}\left(1-\epsilon \delta^{D}(\mathbf{r})\right)=\epsilon W_{2}(0, t) \end{align*}⟨x⟩t+12​​−⟨x⟩t2​​​=21​−41​r∑​[W2​(r,t+1)−W2​(r,t)]r2≃21​−41​∫ dDrr2∇2[W2​(1−ϵδD(r)+⋯)]≃21​−21​∫ dDrW2​(1−ϵδD(r))=ϵW2​(0,t)​(10.138)​

Summing both sides of this equation over ttt, one finds

⟨x(t+1)⟩2‾=ϵ∑t′=0tW2(0,t′)≈∫0t dt′(4πt′)−D/2\begin{equation*} \overline{\langle x(t+1)\rangle^{2}}=\epsilon \sum_{t^{\prime}=0}^{t} W_{2}\left(0, t^{\prime}\right) \approx \int_{0}^{t} \mathrm{~d} t^{\prime}\left(4 \pi t^{\prime}\right)^{-D / 2} \tag{10.139} \end{equation*}⟨x(t+1)⟩2​=ϵt′=0∑t​W2​(0,t′)≈∫0t​ dt′(4πt′)−D/2​(10.139)​

The final integral is proportional to the time a random walker spends at the origin, and reproduces the results in Eq. (10.135).

We can also regard W2(r,t)W_{2}(r, t)W2​(r,t) as a probability distribution function for the relative coordinate between two interacting random walkers. In this interpretation, the value of ϵ\epsilonϵ in Eq. (10.133) parameterizes the strength of a contact interaction between the walkers. If ϵ=0\epsilon=0ϵ=0, the walkers do not interact at all; if ϵ=1\epsilon=1ϵ=1, the walkers bind on contact. According to Eq. (10.139), the wandering of the beam center ⟨x(t)⟩⟩2‾\overline{\langle x(t)\rangle\rangle^{2}}⟨x(t)⟩⟩2​ is proportional to the mean number of times that the paths of these walkers intersect during time ttt. If ϵ=0\epsilon=0ϵ=0, the number of intersections during time ttt obeys the scaling law in Eq. (10.135), since in this case, the relative coordinate between the walkers performs a simple random walk. Numerical results indicate that the same scaling law applies when 0<ϵ<10<\epsilon<10<ϵ<1 : the contact attraction does not affect the asymptotic properties of the random walk. In summary, three classes of behavior are possible in this model. For ϵ=0\epsilon=0ϵ=0, i.e. no randomness, the incoming beam stays centered at the origin, while its width grows diffusively. For 0<ϵ<10<\epsilon<10<ϵ<1, the beam center, ⟨x⟩2‾\overline{\langle x\rangle^{2}}⟨x⟩2​, also fluctuates, but with a dimension dependent behavior as in Eq. (10.135). In the limit of ϵ=1\epsilon=1ϵ=1, interference phenomena disappear completely. In this case, the beam width is zero and the beam center performs a simple random walk.

We conclude by comparing the situation here to that of the DPRM. In the replica approach to DPRM, the nnn-th moment of the weight W(x,t)W(x, t)W(x,t) is obtained from the statistics of nnn directed paths. Disorder-averaging produces an attractive interaction between these paths with the result that they may form a bound state. In d≤2d \leq 2d≤2, any amount of randomness (and hence attraction) leads to the formation of a bound state. The behavior of the bound state energy can then be used to extract an exponent of ζ=2/3\zeta=2 / 3ζ=2/3 for superdiffusive wandering. By contrast, the replicated paths encountered in the directed wave problem (such as the two paths considered for Eq. 10.131), although interacting, cannot form a bound state, as such is inconsistent with unitarity. This result also emerges in a natural way from our model of directed waves. In d=2d=2d=2, for instance, it is easy to check that W2(r)∼(1−ϵδr,0)−1W_{2}(\mathbf{r}) \sim\left(1-\epsilon \delta_{r, 0}\right)^{-1}W2​(r)∼(1−ϵδr,0​)−1 is the eigenstate of largest eigenvalue for the evolution of the relative coordinate. Hence, as t→∞t \rightarrow \inftyt→∞, for randomness δ\deltaδ-correlated in space and time, there is no bound state. This conclusion holds in d≥2d \geq 2d≥2 and is not modified by short-range correlations in the randomness. The probability-conserving nature of Eq. (10.133) is crucial in this regard [F. Igloi, Europhys. Lett. 16, 171 (1991)] as it precludes a uδD(r)u \delta^{D}(\mathbf{r})uδD(r) attraction in Eq. (10.136). Small perturbations that violate the conservation of probability lead to the formation of a bound state. In the language of the renormalization group, the scaling of directed waves in random media is governed by a fixed point that is unstable with respect to changes that do not preserve a strictly unitary evolution.

In subsequent studies a number of authors have obtained additional results from the random SSS-matrix model. Friedberg and Yu [R. Friedberg and Y.-K. Yu, Phys. Rev. E 49, 5755 (1994)] calculated the leading terms in the scaling laws for the beam center in d≥2d \geq 2d≥2, and also the next-order corrections. The analytical results are in agreement with those presented above. Cule and Shapir [D. Cule and Y. Shapir, Phys. Rev. B 50, 5119 (1994)] extended the methods of this section to compute the higher moments of the probability distribution for directed waves in random media. If this probability distribution is multifractal, as claimed in [J.-P. Bouchaud, D. Touati, and D. Sornette, Phys. Rev. Lett. 68, 1787 (1992)] the higher moments should obey new scaling laws whose exponents are not simply related to those of the lower moments. Within the framework of the SSS-matrix model, Cule and Shapir did not find evidence for multifractal scaling, while suggesting that certain aspects of the scaling behavior may be sensitive to details of the unitary time evolution. The above model has also found applications in diverse contexts such as force chains in granular media, and surface of quantum Hall multilayers [M. Lewandowska, H. Mathur, and Y.-K. Yu, Phys. Rev. E 64, 026107 (2001)].
